entries.name: Age
entries: Tabaxi live an average of 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Tabaxi are taller on average than humans and relatively slender. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have a cat's keen senses, especially in the dark. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Feline Agility
entries: Your reflexes and agility allow you to move with a burst of speed. When you move on your turn in combat, you can double your speed until the end of the turn. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you move 0 feet on one of your turns.

entries.name: Cat's Claws
entries: Because of your claws, you have a climbing speed of 20 feet. In addition, your claws are natural weapons, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with them, you deal slashing damage equal to 1d4 + your Strength modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

entries.name: Cat's Talents
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Perception} and {@skill Stealth} skills.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Orc'Mar
Follow the Cat Lord Wullo: explore and discover secrets and if necessary, deal in death.

The Tabaxi come from two parts of the Badlands. To the west and south of New Hope is the Fertile Valley. It is the ancestral home of many species, including the Tabaxi. In recent times the Hobgoblins leadership has grown incredibly powerful and organized. The Puma and Leopard Tabaxi that are native have been drive from their homes. Some clans have been all but wiped out causing the survivors to wander into other parts of the Badlands seeking a home.

The second area, far to the north and west are a series of hills, home to the Lion Tabaxi. They are a prideful breed and they will occasionally wander throughout the Badlands seeking their faith. The Lion Tabaxi find the corruption and infection to be the greatest of evil and often dedicate their lives to eradicating it.

entries.name: Age
entries: Lizardfolk live an average of 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Lizardfolk are a little bulkier and taller than humans, and their colorful frills make them appear even larger. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Swim Speed
entries: You have a swimming speed of 30 feet.

entries.name: Bite
entries: Your fanged maw is a natural weapon, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with it, you deal piercing damage equal to 1d6 + your Strength modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

entries.name: Cunning Artisan
entries: As part of a short rest, you can harvest bone and hide from a slain beast, construct, dragon, monstrosity, or plant creature of size small or larger to create one of the following items: a {@item shield|phb}, a {@item club|phb}, a {@item javelin|phb}, or {@dice 1d4} {@item dart|phb|darts} or {@item blowgun needle|phb|blowgun needles}. To use this trait, you need a blade, such as a {@item dagger|phb}, or appropriate artisan's tools, such as {@item leatherworker's tools|phb}.

entries.name: Hold Breath
entries: You can hold your breath for up to 15 minutes at a time.

entries.name: Hunter's Lore
entries: You gain proficiency with two of the following skills of your choice: {@skill Animal Handling}, {@skill Nature}, {@skill Perception}, {@skill Stealth}, and {@skill Survival}.

entries.name: Natural Armor
entries: You have tough, scaly skin. When you aren't wearing armor, your AC is 13 + your Dexterity modifier. You can use your natural armor to determine your AC if the armor you wear would leave you with a lower AC. A shield's benefits apply as normal while you use your natural armor.

entries.name: Hungry Jaws
entries: In battle, you can throw yourself into a vicious feeding frenzy. As a bonus action, you can make a special attack with your bite. If the attack hits, it deals its normal damage, and you gain temporary hit points equal to your Constitution modifier (minimum of 1), and you can't use this trait again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Draconic.
We must rise above simple fear, aggression and pleasure.

The Lizardfolk come from one of the 3 swamps in the Badlands. The nearest swamp, called Odessaanen by the natives, lies just south and a bit west of New Hope. The lizardfolk there are divided into two camps, the wisdom seeking Blacktooth and the Titan worshiping, cannibalistic Kotharluath, or Kothar. Their civil war is almost 10 years old and no one could easily say who is winning. Due to the dangerous nature of the swamp and the challenge of finding resources the civil war will frequently die down to a low simmer for seasons as both sides recuperate.

The Blacktooth are tribal and have small communities throughout the swamp. Their capital, Guhadha'xa, is a large town in size. It is the hub for the spiritual elders of the community and for trade. Before the war, the lizardfolk worked hard to protect their lands, keep their young safe and make a home for themselves. They revered the nine, but mostly Busana and Liisa. They tried to fight their natural inclination towards fear, aggression and pleasure. Many of them would find outlets in swimming competitions, wrestling and other physical activities that would burn off the passions of the body. A lizardfolk who seeks enlightenment likely has a great internal struggle between their lizard brain and their will to be something more.

After the war, the lizardfolk's struggle for enlightenment became far more difficult. The psychic toll of knowing a great threat existed in the swamp waiting to eat them was immeasurable. The relatively regular fighting led them towards their more base tendencies. This war is not about territory only, but also about the spirits of the people.

entries.name: Age
entries: Gnomes live an average of 75 years

entries.name: Size
entries: Gnomes are between 3 and 4 feet tall and average about 40 pounds. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Gnome Cunning
entries: You have advantage on all Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws against magic.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Thorran.

entries.name: Size
entries: A typical svirfneblin stands about 3 to 3½ feet tall and weighs 80 to 120 pounds. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Superior Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 120 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Stone Camouflage
entries: You have advantage on Dexterity ({@condition Stealth}) checks to hide in rocky terrain.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Deepcommon, and Orc'Mar.
Also called Svirfneblin. Live in the Deep Below, some worship Lutu. Many can be found in Meridiem.

entries.name: Natural Illusionist
entries: You know the {@spell minor illusion} cantrip. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for it.

entries.name: Speak with Small Beasts
entries: Through sounds and gestures, you can communicate simple ideas with Small or smaller beasts. Forest gnomes love animals and often keep squirrels, badgers, rabbits, moles, woodpeckers, and other creatures as beloved pets.
We were the children of evil. The gods adopted us. Revere them. Faith is the answer.

For a people that believe that we are descended from pure evil they sure do squeeze a lot of happiness out of their lives. They try to live with goodness and joy in their hearts because they know they are the descendants of the evil cold blooded dragons and the hot blooded ancient titans. Gnomes kept to the fringes of society. They were among all of the other races but still separate from them. They suffered from some racism and bigotry due to their size and mysterious nature. When the infection came, no one gave them second mind and so their communities were able to uproot and relocate. They were not without their losses.

entries.name: Artificer's Lore
entries: Whenever you make an Intelligence ({@skill History}) check related to magic items, alchemical objects, or technological devices, you can add twice your proficiency bonus, instead of any proficiency bonus you normally apply.

entries.name: Tinker
entries: You have proficiency with artisan's tools ({@item tinker's tools|phb}). Using those tools, you can spend 1 hour and 10 gp worth of materials to construct a Tiny clockwork device (AC 5, 1 hp). The device ceases to function after 24 hours (unless you spend 1 hour repairing it to keep the device functioning), or when you use your action to dismantle it; at that time, you can reclaim the materials used to create it. You can have up to three such devices active at a time.
When you create a device, choose one of the following options:

entries.name: Clockwork Toy
entries: This toy is a clockwork animal, monster, or person, such as a frog, mouse, bird, dragon, or soldier. When placed on the ground, the toy moves 5 feet across the ground on each of your turns in a random direction. It makes noises as appropriate to the creature it represents.

entries.name: Fire Starter
entries: The device produces a miniature flame, which you can use to light a candle, torch, or campfire. Using the device requires your action.

entries.name: Music Box
entries: When opened, this music box plays a single song at a moderate volume. The box stops playing when it reaches the song's end or when it is closed.
We were the children of evil. The gods adopted us. Revere them. Faith is the answer.

For a people that believe that we are descended from pure evil they sure do squeeze a lot of happiness out of their lives. They try to live with goodness and joy in their hearts because they know they are the descendants of the evil cold blooded dragons and the hot blooded ancient titans. Gnomes kept to the fringes of society. They were among all of the other races but still separate from them. They suffered from some racism and bigotry due to their size and mysterious nature. When the infection came, no one gave them second mind and so their communities were able to uproot and relocate. They were not without their losses.

entries.name: Age
entries: Loxodons have an average lifespan of 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Loxodons stand between 7 and 8 feet tall. Their massive bodies weigh between 300 and 400 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: You count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.

entries.name: Loxodon Serenity
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

entries.name: Natural Armor
entries: You have thick, leathery skin. When you aren't wearing armor, your AC is 12 + your Constitution modifier. You can use your natural armor to determine your AC if the armor you wear would leave you with a lower AC. A shield's benefits apply as normal while you use your natural armor.

entries.name: Tip: AC Calculations Don't Stack
entries: When the game gives you more than one way to calculate your Armor Class, you can use only one of them. You choose the one to use. For example, if you have the loxodon's Natural Armor trait and the monk's Unarmored Defense feature, you don't mix them together. Instead, you choose which one determines your AC.

entries.name: Trunk
entries: You can grasp things with your trunk, and you can use it as a snorkel. It has a reach of 5 feet, and it can lift a number of pounds equal to five times your Strength score. You can use it to do the following simple tasks: lift, drop, hold, push, or pull an object or a creature; open or close a door or a container; grapple someone; or make an unarmed strike. Your DM might allow other simple tasks to be added to that list of options. Your trunk can't wield weapons or shields or do anything that requires manual precision, such as using tools or magic items or performing the somatic components of a spell.

entries.name: Keen Smell
entries: Thanks to your sensitive trunk, you have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}), Wisdom ({@skill Survival}), and Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) checks that rely on smell.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Deepcommon and Orc'Mar.
Mysterious origins, small enclave in Meridiem.

entries.name: Size
entries: Shifters are about the same size as humans. Your size is Medium

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Keen Senses
entries: You have proficiency with the Perception skill.

entries.name: Shifting
entries: On your turn, you can shift as a bonus action. Shifting lasts for 1 minute or until you end it on your turn as a bonus action.
While shifting, you gain temporary hit points equal to your level + your Constitution bonus (minimum of 1). You also gain a feature that depends on your shifter subrace, described below.
You must finish a short or long rest before you can shift again.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Deepcommon.

entries.name: Natural Tracker
entries: You have proficiency with the Survival skill.

entries.name: Mark the Scent
entries: As a bonus action, you can mark one creature you can see within 10 feet of you.

Until the end of your next long rest, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make to find the marked creature, and you always know the location of that creature if it is within 60 feet of you.
You can't use this trait again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Shifting Feature
entries: While shifting, you gain advantage on all Wisdom-based checks.

entries.name: Tough
entries: You have proficiency with {@skill Athletics}.

entries.name: Shifting Feature
entries: While shifting, you gain 1d6 additional temporary hit points, and while shifted, you have a +1 bonus to your AC.

entries.name: Graceful
entries: You have proficiency with the Acrobatics skill.

entries.name: Swift Stride
entries: Your walking speed increases by 5 feet.

entries.name: Shifting Feature
entries: While shifted, your walking speed increases by 5 feet. Additionally, you can move up to 10 feet as a reaction when an enemy ends its turn within 5 feet of you. This movement doesn't provoke opportunity attacks.

entries.name: Fierce
entries: You have proficiency with the Intimidation skill.

entries.name: Shifting Feature
entries: While shifted, you can use your elongated fangs to make an unarmed strike as a bonus action. If you hit with your fangs, you can deal piercing damage equal to 1d6 + your Strength modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

The shifters seem to have evolved from twin soul lycanthropes. Further details of their origins are shrouded in mystery. Ruthlessly hunted by almost all on the surface, they fled to the Deep Below for refuge. Several factions live in Meridiem, often in poverty. Lycanthropes often hunt them as bastards that refused to support them against their enemies.

All shifters are partially bestial in appearance. This can range from subtle facial structures like a slightly protruding canine snout, slitted eyes, or some other feature. Shifters are easily identifiable as shifters at close range. At a range where one might reasonably not recognize a particular person's face, a shifter might get mistaken for human.

When using their shifting power, shifters appear considerably more bestial while staying humanoid. They do not take on full hybrid forms like true lycanthropes but their animalistic features exaggerate, or they take on new ones relevant to their breed. A beasthide shifter, for example, might have their muscles swell beyond human proportions or have their skin toughen and grow thicker. While shifted, they can easily be spotted for what they are even at distance.

race.name: Triton

entries.name: Age
entries: Tritons live an average of 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Tritons are slightly shorter than humans, averaging about 5 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Swim Speed
entries: You have a swimming speed of 30 feet.

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: You can breathe air and water.

entries.name: Control Air and Water
entries: A child of the sea, you can call on the magic of elemental air and water. You can cast {@spell fog cloud} with this trait. Starting at 3rd level, you can cast {@spell gust of wind} with it, and starting at 5th level, you can also cast {@spell wall of water|xge} with it. Once you cast a spell with this trait, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Emissary of the Sea
entries: Aquatic beasts have an extraordinary affinity with your people. You can communicate simple ideas with beasts that can breathe water. They can understand the meaning of your words, though you have no special ability to understand them in return.

entries.name: Guardians of the Depths
entries: Adapted to even the most extreme ocean depths, you have resistance to cold damage, and you ignore any of the drawbacks caused by a deep, underwater environment.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and The Royal Speech of the Shining Tritons.

The main colony is at the floor of the Shining Sea. Tunnels connect it via underwater to the Deep Below and Meridiem. Adventurous Tritons may make their way there, Fighting various underwater menaces.

languageTags: The Royal Speech of the Shining Tritons

entries.name: Size
entries: Goblins are between 3 and 4 feet tall and weigh between 40 and 80 pounds. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Nimble Escape
entries: You can take the Disengage or Hide action as a bonus action on each of your turns.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Fury of the Small
entries: When you damage a creature with an attack or a spell and the creature's size is larger than yours, you can cause the attack or spell to deal extra damage to the creature. The extra damage equals your level. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Orc'Mar or Lutun.
Expect the unexpected!

You are probably a member of the Silver Ribbon tribe of goblins. Your tribe lived in the Badlands for generations. Your shamans prayed to Rhion. Your god lead you clear of danger. There was a feud among the leaders and you aren't sure what happened. One of your strongest, Tikillik, left with almost half the tribe.

A few months after their departure, your remaining people started being hunted by misshapen goblins hailing from the Rat Tribe. When they would capture one of you, they would eat them! They are cannibals. Brave adventurers in New Hope saved the last few survivors of your tribe and you live among them now.

entries.name: Superior Darkvision
entries: Superior Darkvision. You can see in dim light within 120 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Deepcommon and Lutun.
Goblins that live in Meridiem. Their skin is a lighter grey from living underground and their vision is superior in the dark.

entries.name: Size
entries: Orcs are somewhat larger and bulkier than humans, and they range from 5 to well over 6 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Menacing
entries: You gain proficiency in the Intimidation skill.

entries.name: Relentless Endurance
entries: When you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead. You can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Savage Attacks
entries: When you score a critical hit with a melee weapon attack, you can roll one of the weapon's damage dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage of the critical hit.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Orc'Mar.
Hold close the ones you care for, clan above all.”

Living in the shadow of Giantholm, the Orcs are known for the strength of their tight knit clans. More than any other race they claim the Badlands as their native home. The orcs possess a natural strength that others find intimidating. Though they are often divided into many small clans it is not unheard of for a warlord to emerge and unite the orcs against a common foe. The last time this was done was against the armies of Alt Walav. The ensuing battles led to a negotiation, peace and finally the orcs being formally invited to join the kingdom as citizens.

entries.name: Proud And Strong
entries: Orcs skin is gray, gray green or greenish in pigment. They have sloping foreheads, a strong brow and jaw line and large curved tusks. They are towering, some rising over 7 feet in height. The men and women are of equal size and ferocity.

Each clan has a different relationship with scars / scarring, branding, tattooing and piercing. The art of body modification, the pain and the process, is often a rite of passage. It is widely regarded as a sign of weakness to have scars on your back, marking you for cowardice.

entries.name: Descendants Of War
entries: The orcs can trace their descent directly from the war between the Titans and the Dragons. The giant slaves of the titans, the orc forefathers, rebelled and walked away from war. They formed clans or tribes and fiercely fought off their former masters.

The orcs ancestry brings with it strong emotions, love, lust, rage and happiness felt in abundance. Binding all orcs together, stronger than any of their primal instincts, is the clan and those close to you. It is not uncommon to see orcs fight, draw blood, make new scars and end up friends afterwards.

entries.name: Orc Names
entries: The orc language, closely related to dwarf, is gutteral and harsh sounding. As such, so are the names of the orcish brothers and sisters that roam the Badlands.

entries.name: Male Orc Names
entries: Dench, Feng, Gell, Henk, Holg, Imsh, Keth, Krusk, Mhurren, Ront, Shump, Thokk

entries.name: Female Orc Names
entries: Baggi, Emen, Engong, Kansif, Myev, Neega, Ovak, Ownka, Shautha, Vola, Volen, Yevelda

entries.name: Superior Darkvision
entries: Superior Darkvision. You can see in dim light within 120 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Deepcommon and Orc'Mar.
Our clans are meant to rule, the Golden Circle above all.”

Orcs spread out across the Badlands. Hundres of years ago several clans descended into the Deep Below. They found Meridiem and were invited by whatever strange powers lived there. They learned that they are far superior than most at controlling the chaos that abounds in the city. The Golden circle was formed, the greatest orc clan, and it has held the first position in Meridiem for a long time.

entries.name: Adapted To The Deep Below
entries: Meridiem orcs spend their time underground and their skin is a lighter gray. Their eyes have changed, some becoming violet. They can see in the dark far better than their surface cousins. They are also far more lawful and organized than their surface cousins. Many carry a hefty superiority complex.

entries.name: Age
entries: Elves live an average of 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Elves range from under 5 to over 6 feet tall and have slender builds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to twilit forests and the night sky, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Keen Senses
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Perception} skill.

entries.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and magic can't put you to sleep.

entries.name: Trance
entries: Elves don't need to sleep. Instead, they meditate deeply, remaining semiconscious, for 4 hours a day. (The Common word for such meditation is "trance.") While meditating, you can dream after a fashion; such dreams are actually mental exercises that have become reflexive through years of practice. After resting in this way, you gain the same benefit that a human does from 8 hours of sleep.
{@note If you meditate during a long rest, you finish the rest after only 4 hours. You otherwise obey all the rules for a long rest; only the duration is changed.}

entries.name: Inferior Darkvision
entries: As a desert dwelling race, constantly under the bright sun, your darkvision only extends to 30 feet.

entries.name: Sunlight Resistance
entries: The colour of your skin and your constant exposure to extreme heat make it so you do not suffer the normal detrimental effects of extreme warm weather and desert climates.

entries.name: Poets and Singers
entries: Dark elves gain proficiency in Performance.

entries.name: Dark Elf Magic
entries: You know the {@spell dancing lights} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell faerie fire} spell once per day; you must finish a long rest in order to cast the spell again using this trait. When you reach 5th level, you can also cast the {@spell darkness} spell once per day; you must finish a long rest in order to cast the spell again using this trait. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Mowibban.
Become your best self, the path is through self expression and art.”

The dark elves are desert dwelling tribal people. They populate the Desert of Golden Radiance. They sing songs to carry their traditions and dance around the bonfire. Their communities are divided between the wealthy merchants, some of which are slavers, and the indigenous desert tribes that try to be one with nature. The desert is a brutal master and the dark elves that survive are a tough people. When the infection came to their lands it engulfed the massive tent cities. The dark elves fled into the desert where the hot sun protected them. Many more infected died of starvation and exposure than to the weapons of the dark elves. The dark elves believe that each has a song within them. Learning that song and singing it out loud is the truest expression of the self. This inner song grows and changes with the shape of the life of the elf. The high elven ways run opposite to the dark elves. This tension has led to more than one mocking ballad, midnight duel or minor battle. The great tragedy Romero and Juliana tells the tail of a high elf and dark elf and forbidden love.

entries.name: Elf Weapon Training
entries: You have proficiency with the {@item longsword|phb}, {@item shortsword|phb}, {@item shortbow|phb}, and {@item longbow|phb}.

entries.name: Cantrip
entries: You know one {@filter cantrip of your choice from the wizard spell list|spells|level=0|class=Wizard}. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for it.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Linav've.

entries.name: Extra Language
entries: You can speak, read, and write one extra language of your choosing.
Become your best self, your higher self must rule through reason.”

The High elves have integrated into Alt Walav thoroughly. Their magic and their intelligence are highly prized and Fekwen encourages fair trade between the races. The traditional homeland of the High Elves, Oalon Linavon, lies very far to the east, accessible only across the shining sea. The infection did not reach your ancestral lands. Or at least, it hasn't yet. The High elves believe that the inner self has a lower order and a higher order. The lower order suffers from desire and temptation. The higher order allows one to find your true calling and purpose and to bring you to happiness. The higher order, closely associated with logic, is the prize that all high elves are taught to pursue and master. Many say that the high elves are masters of willpower, self control and logical thought. Others call them cold and calculated.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Linav've Maldavani.

entries.name: Elf Weapon Training
entries: You have proficiency with the {@item longsword|phb}, {@item shortsword|phb}, {@item shortbow|phb}, and {@item longbow|phb}.

entries.name: Fleet of Foot
entries: Your base walking speed increases to 35 feet.

entries.name: Mask of the Wild
entries: You can attempt to hide even when you are only lightly obscured by foliage, heavy rain, falling snow, mist, and other natural phenomena.
Become your best self, the path to enlightenment is to listen to intuition.

The Wood Elves share the kingdom of Maldavan with the humans. They stay to the forest areas, the Black Wood, the Dire Wood and the Fabled Wood are their main homes. They live among nature, sharing the land with the indigenous residents. The wood elves have made alliances with the sylvan creatures and the less violent lycanthrope tribes. This alliance was tested when the infected came. Many fell and many more ran. Only the natural hazards of the forest stopped the hordes from growing to innumerable size. It is rumoured that great wood elven druids used magic to summon the forest folk and managed to keep the infected from the very core of the woods, but at a great cost. Unlike their cousins the high elves, they do not believe in a higher order and lower order. They are guided by intuition, an inner voice that is in touch with the divine and the natural. If one can force out all of the distracting noises of the world and listen to your inner intuition you will find the right path for you.

entries.name: Age
entries: A halfling lives an average of 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Halflings average about 3 feet tall and weigh about 40 pounds. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Lucky
entries: When you roll a 1 on an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll.

entries.name: Brave
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

entries.name: Halfling Nimbleness
entries: You can move through the space of any creature that is of a size larger than yours.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Maldavani.

entries.name: Naturally Stealthy
entries: You can attempt to hide even when you are obscured only by a creature that is at least one size larger than you.

entries.name: Stout Resilience
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.

entries.name: Silent Speech
entries: You can speak telepathically to any creature within 30 feet of you. The creature understands you only if the two of you share a language. You can speak telepathically in this way to one creature at a time.
Fatalists, everything happens for a reason.

The halflings are nomadic and wander all lands. They believe that where they end up, they arrived for a reason. All things happen for a reason. Asking why leads to unhappiness and frustration. Allow fate to play out. The god Rhion, who finds a way around any obstacle, is nearest and dearest to the halfling heart. The halfling families suffered in similar ways to whichever kingdom they were in when the hordes came. Their small stature and cunning allowed many to escape.

Their exclusion from conscription to most armies allowed their able bodied warriors and magicians to focus on saving their kin. It is said that a great hero of the halfling people established a caravan train with the fastest horses and would enter areas filled with infected and rescue anyone of any race that needed it. This Green Rider is a modern hero and a central story of hope in dark times.

entries.name: Age
entries: Dragonborn live an average of 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Dragonborn are taller and heavier than humans, standing well over 6 feet tall and averaging almost 250 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Draconic Ancestry
entries: You have draconic ancestry. Choose one type of dragon from the Draconic Ancestry table. Your breath weapon and damage resistance are determined by the dragon type, as shown in the table.

entries.caption: Draconic Ancestry
rows: Black
Acid
5 by 30 ft. line (Dex. save)
Blue
Lightning
5 by 30 ft. line (Dex. save)
Brass
Fire
5 by 30 ft. line (Dex. save)
Bronze
Lightning
5 by 30 ft. line (Dex. save)
Copper
Acid
5 by 30 ft. line (Dex. save)
Gold
Fire
15 ft. cone (Dex. save)
Green
Poison
15 ft. cone (Con. save)
Red
Fire
15 ft. cone (Dex. save)
Silver
Cold
15 ft. cone (Con. save)
White
Cold
15 ft. cone (Con. save)

entries.name: Breath Weapon
entries: You can use your action to exhale destructive energy. Your draconic ancestry determines the size, shape, and damage type of the exhalation.

When you use your breath weapon, each creature in the area of the exhalation must make a saving throw, the type of which is determined by your draconic ancestry. The DC for this saving throw equals 8 + your Constitution modifier + your proficiency bonus. A creature takes 2d6 damage on a failed save, and half as much damage on a successful one. The damage increases to 3d6 at 6th level, 4d6 at 11th level, and 5d6 at 16th level.
After you use your breath weapon, you can't use it again until you complete a short or long rest.

entries.name: Damage Resistance
entries: You have resistance to the damage type associated with your draconic ancestry.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Draconic.
Destiny is written, find your place. Death reveals your truth. Heed the prophecies.

The dragonborn are the direct descendants of dragons. They turned away from their forefathers, shed their wings and adopted civilization. With community, magic and massive armies they hunted the dragons in the Empire of Yan to near extinction. They became obsessed with their destiny. They thought it was to conquer. Once dragons became hard to find they turned their eyes towards the Yuan Ti people, a introspective snake people. The wars were one sided, and the Yuan Ti had to flee their lands. The dragonborn control their borders fiercely and the infection never made it into their lands. Their young travel as part of their coming of age rituals. Additionally, a dragonborn considers the moment of death to be the defining event in meeting destiny. As such the death penalty is non existent, serious criminals are exiled.

entries.name: Age
entries: Yuan-ti live an average of 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Yuan-ti match humans in average size and weight. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: You know the {@spell poison spray} cantrip. You can cast {@spell animal friendship} an unlimited number of times with this trait, but you can target only snakes with it. Starting at 3rd level, you can also cast {@spell suggestion} with this trait. Once you cast it, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Magic Resistance
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

entries.name: Poison Resistance
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Draconic.
Only through self awareness will we rise above the savages.

The Yuan Ti were a reclusive, introspective people from the swamps of mourning. They listened to the guidance of Busana of the moon, the huntress. They wrote poetry and concerned themselves with self awareness and introspection.

When the dragonborn of Yan came they were not prepared. Many died. No demon infected horde plagued these people. They were nearly totally wiped out by the genocidal dragonborn. It is unknown what finally stopped the dragonborn onslaught. It is whispered that high priests of the Yuan Ti people and the high priests of the dragonborn of Yan saw a common ground through their gods and that ended the slaughter.
If you are a Yuan Ti then you likely felt the need to travel due to a curiosity about the world.

entries.name: Age
entries: Goliaths have lifespans of about 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Goliaths are between 7 and 8 feet tall and weigh between 280 and 340 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Natural Athlete
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Athletics} skill.

entries.name: Stone's Endurance
entries: You can focus yourself to occasionally shrug off injury. When you take damage, you can use your reaction to roll a d12. Add your Constitution modifier to the number rolled, and reduce the damage by that total. After you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: You count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.

entries.name: Mountain Born
entries: You're acclimated to high altitude, including elevations above 20,000 feet. You're also naturally adapted to cold climates, as described in chapter 5 of the Dungeon Master's Guide.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Cursed Speech.
We are the descendants of the ancient and evil Titans. We will work tirelessly to bring good to the land and repair what our forefathers did.

The Goliaths are direct descendants of the ancient titans and the smallest of the giant folk that claim that ancestry. They are a tribal culture, keeping the good of the collective above that of the individual. A short description of Goliaths might be “big and moral”. They seek to do right by everyone to make up for their ancestry, and for the actions of their more sinister cousins, the ogres and their giant cousins. The Goliath life is of a peaceful worker, a helpful clergy, or a great warrior that stomps out evil. When the infected hordes plagued the lands of the humans, elves, dwarves and other smaller races the goliaths gathered into great bands and marched to the aid of the little people. Many were lost saving towns and villages. The goliaths did not seek to throw their lives away and began to turn back from regions that were totally lost. Goliaths are now held in very high regard for how many of the other races they saved.

entries.name: Age
entries: Firbolgs live an average of 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Firbolg are between 7 and 8 feet tall and weigh between 240 and 300 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Firbolg Magic
entries: You can cast {@spell detect magic} and {@spell disguise self} with this trait, using Wisdom as your spellcasting ability for them. Once you cast either spell, you can't cast it again with this trait until you finish a short or long rest. When you use this version of {@spell disguise self}, you can seem up to 3 feet shorter than normal, allowing you to more easily blend in with humans and elves.

entries.name: Hidden Step
entries: As a bonus action, you can magically turn {@condition invisible} until the start of your next turn or until you attack, make a damage roll, or force someone to make a saving throw. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: You count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.

entries.name: Speech of Beast and Leaf
entries: You have the ability to communicate in a limited manner with beasts and plants. They can understand the meaning of your words, though you have no special ability to understand them in return. You have advantage on all Charisma checks you make to influence them.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Linav've.
We have made peace with the ancient giant blood in our veins. We are one with nature and we protect small folk.”

These mysterious people descent from forest giants. Many generations ago a powerful wizard sought to protect his people. He created a pocket realm within the forest. He folded the forest creating a home for his people. There were several secret entry points to the new home of the firbolgs and they were safe. Just recently it was discovered that the magic was not keeping the monstrosities out but instead absorbing them like a sponge and keeping them in suspended animation. Over time the magic could not contain and control the 100s of monstrosities trapped within. It started to faulter and occasionally spit them out. Adventurers from New Hope investigated and discovered the root of the magic. A choice had to be made, collapse the pocket back into Morra or forever sever the connection. They chose to have the firbolgs rejoin the Badlands to struggle for survival.

Two factions have developed among the firbolg in the last 50 or so years. The traditionalists seek to remain separate from others and keep the firbolg culture secret and the way it has always been. The young explorers, often called revolutionaries, seek to rejoin the other good races and find their place in the world. They think that only together do the firbolgs have a chance to battle back the darkness.

entries.name: Age
entries: Krynn live an average of 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Minotaurs typically stand well over 6 feet tall and weigh an average of 300 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Horns
entries: You are never unarmed. You are proficient with your horns, which are a melee weapon that deals 1d10 piercing damage. Your horns grant you advantage on all checks made to shove a creature, but not to avoid being shoved yourself.

entries.name: Goring Rush
entries: When you use the {@action Dash} action during your turn, you can make a melee attack with your horns as a bonus action.

entries.name: Giant Slayer
entries: You may perform the special attack shove to prone against a giant or minotaur with advantage and ignoring size restrictions.The herd’s warriors practice where to strike giants to knock them on their ass.

entries.name: Bull's Endurance
entries: You gain proficiency with {@skill athletics}.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Cursed Speech.
Wisdom weave our path and guide us clear of danger, disease and rash decisions.

The blood of the evil Titans flows freely in many of the giant races: ogres, hill giants, and of course minotaurs. But not all embrace this evil. The Krynn, or wisebloods, have found peace through the worship of Ghem, Mythral/Kordda and Igna. They sacrificed much of their size and power in exchange for wisdom, forethought and a chance at a good life.

The Wisebloods formed into nomadic herds that travel the Badlands, moving from food source to food source. A herd is led by a herd leader, the wisest of them all. They seek to weave a path to avoiding conflict when they can. That is, unless giantfolk are involved. Then the Krynn unanimously don their wargear and venture out to fell the creature. They warriors rush forth boldly and strike at the giants knees and hips, toppling them, so that the rest of the herd can easily finish them off.

entries.name: Age
entries: Tieflings live an average of 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Tieflings are about the same size and build as humans. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Thanks to your infernal heritage, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Hellish Resistance
entries: You have resistance to fire damage.

entries.name: Infernal Legacy
entries: You know the {@spell thaumaturgy} cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell hellish rebuke} spell as a 2nd-level spell; you must finish a long rest in order to cast the spell again using this trait. Once you reach 5th level, you can also cast the {@spell darkness} spell; you must finish a long rest in order to cast the spell again using this trait. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Aethersea'al.
You're stuck with us, deal with it.

The Destroyer Helm crisis made the barrier between worlds weak. Many devils crossed to take advantage of the weaker mortals. They sought to make deals, gain power and steal magical items. They did not count on falling in love...

While rare, a devil and a mortal would bond and have a child. The offspring were born of this world and as the barrier between worlds strengthened again, they were not cast back to the Aetherial plane. Tieflings are stuck in this world, have likely lost a parent and carry the stigma of being an evil devil. But they make due and some are able to earn the trust of a small community and find a home. A small community such as New Hope.

entries.name: Age
entries: Warbreed live an average of 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Warbreed are about the same size and build as humans. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Thanks to your infernal heritage, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Demonic Fortitude
entries: You select either lightning, or fire, or cold resistance.

entries.name: Destroyer Legacy
entries: You know the {@spell thaumaturgy} cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell detect magic} spell as a 2nd-level spell; you must finish a long rest in order to cast the spell again using this trait. Once you reach 5th level, you can also cast the {@spell crown of madness} spell; you must finish a long rest in order to cast the spell again using this trait. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Infection Immunity
entries: You are immune to the demon plague, infection, demon shivers and all forms of disease that stem from the Destroyer Helm crisis.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Aethersea'al.
We did not choose this.

The Destroyer Helm crisis brought with it the demon plague, sometimes called the infection. At first all of the victims were mindless savages. Something changed in the first years and some of the infected started to retain some feral intelligence. They began behaving like animals. They started to breed. The offspring of these unions are called Warbreed. They are far more intelligent than their parents. It must be that by being born of the material plane they lose the blind rage that comes with the demon plague.
Warbreed are often killed on sight and so they will frequently make their own way in the world. But sometimes small communities will accept a Warbreed.

entries.name: Age
entries: Dwarves live an average of 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Dwarves stand between 4 and 5 feet tall and average about 150 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your speed is not reduced by wearing heavy armor.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.

entries.name: Dwarven Combat Training
entries: You have proficiency with the battleaxe, handaxe, light hammer, and warhammer.

entries.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with the artisan's tools of your choice: {@item Smith's tools|phb}, {@item brewer's supplies|phb}, or {@item mason's tools|phb}.

entries.name: Stonecunning
entries: Whenever you make an Intelligence ({@skill History}) check related to the origin of stonework, you are considered proficient in the {@skill History} skill and add double your proficiency bonus to the check, instead of your normal proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Thorran.

entries.name: Dwarven Toughness
entries: Your hit point maximum increases by 1, and it increases by 1 every time you gain a level.
Hard working utilitarian. No matter what, press on.

The hill dwarves lived in the rich kingdom of Thorria. The dwarves are divided into castes and clans. The oldest families have the most power and wealth while the younger families work hard to rise up within society. Effort and hard work are rewarded. Failure to press on in the face of adversity is the greatest failing for a hill dwarf. When the infection came this attitude of facing adversity head on made them suffer the most of all races. As their armies clashed with the hordes their own numbers would turn into the demon spawn. The army would just press on, facing larger and large hordes, refusing to flee from more and more unfavorable odds.

Many houses were completely wiped out, refusing to give an inch of their ancestral ground to the infected. Eventually the battles were so clearly suicide that the clans turned away and scattered. If you are a hill dwarf you probably suffer from a great racial depression but you hide it by working twice as hard as anyone else at your given task.

entries.name: Dwarven Armor Training
entries: You have proficiency with light and medium armor.
Hard working consequentialists. If it turned out good, it was right.

The mountain dwarves of Thorria work hard at their trades. They dig for ore and gems and harvest tubers and other vegetables on the mountainsides. They divert underground streams to irrigate and supply their cities.

They do what they think will turn out best. When it came time to fight the hordes they were not willing to simply hold ground and fight when there were better options. Cave ins were used to stop larger hordes. Thousands of dwarf cousins died to protect tens of thousands. The mountain dwarves escaped with the least harm among the stout people.

entries.name: Superior Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 120 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Deep Dwarf Resilience
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage. You also have advantage on saving throws against illusions and against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition paralyzed}.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common or Deepcommon and Thorran.

entries.name: Deep Dwarf Magic
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell Enlarge/Reduce} spell on yourself once with this trait, using only the spell's enlarge option. When you reach 5th level, you can cast the {@spell Invisibility} spell on yourself once with this trait. You don't need material components for either spell, and you can't cast them while you're in direct sunlight, although sunlight has no effect on them once cast. You regain the ability to cast these spells with this trait when you finish a long rest. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: You have disadvantage on attack rolls and Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight when you, the target of your attack, or whatever you are trying to perceive is in direct sunlight.
Hard working authoritarian. Listen to the clan-priest elders for their bloodline is strong.
The deep dwarves are closest to the core of the world and to Ghem’s throne. Their clan heads, often high priests, listen to the whispers of their dwarf god and follow his guidance.

There is nothing evil about Deep Dwarves and they do not practice slavery. When the infected came they dedicated resources to their military and the clergy. The priests shaped the stone to make as many bottlenecks as possible. The deep dwarf military employed their massive war machines and ravaged the infected. It is whispered that betrayal is how the deep dwarves fell. The ancient titan of destruction whispered to a priest and he let the hordes in through a chasm.

entries.name: Age
entries: Humans lives an average of 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Humans vary widely in height and build, from barely 5 feet to well over 6 feet tall. Regardless of your position in that range, your size is Medium.

entries.name: Skill Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency in one skill of your choice.

entries.name: Human Determination
entries: When you make an attack roll, an ability check, or a saving throw, you can do so with advantage. Once you use this ability, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Linav've.
Overcome by being the best, reward merit.

The peoples of Maldavan live far to the north and east of New Hope. Their kingdom was the rare meritocracy. One’s rank was determined by how excellent one was at their trade. Warriors were held in the highest regard with divine magic users a close second. A system of Jarl, Reeve and Thane determined rank. Each Jarl gathered Reeves about her and those Reeves maintained a retinue of mounted Thanes. This system led to both the most skilled armies in the world but also the smallest in size.

The demon infection plague hit this land hard because they were never able to muster a large enough force to deal with the hordes of infected. But, their clan like way of life did allow many smaller groups to scatter before the hordes and survive on the fringes of what was society. If you are from Maldavan you probably seek to become best at something.

entries.name: Human Adaptability
entries: When you miss an attack roll, fail an ability check, or a saving throw, you can choose to roll again and take the new result. Once you use this ability, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one of Linav've or Thorran.
Overcome by any means, to the victor the spoils.”

The peoples of Alt Walav live to the east of New Hope in what was the richest, mostly human, kingdom for several ages. Their chief god, Fekwen of the good deal, led to a complex mercantile system that emphasises profit and fairness. Complex taxation systems allowed the monarchy to leverage huge sums of money for their army and infrastructure. No kingdom had as many fully armoured knights (with unbreakable Hawkwood lances) as Alt Walav, nor as many castles.

A few generations ago the Queen’s throne was usurped by the adventurer Vrad Gormr. He beheaded her on the front steps of the palace and took the throne. Over the next three years there were a record number of beheadings at the kings very own hands, including 3 Jarls from Maladvan that tested him. The queen did not die due to powerful magic. She sought out the destroyer helm and created the demon infection. She was insane with a desire for revenge and the horde of infected spread far beyond Alt Walav.

Now the kingdom is in ruins. Communication and trade between cities is nearly impossible with the hordes roaming the countryside. Some cities are broken with only small clusters of non infected holding out while others have managed to keep the infection outside their walls. For them the trouble is maintaining rations and clean water.

items.name: Skill Proficiency
items.entry: {@skill Insight}, {@skill Religion}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: Choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: Two of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a {@item holy symbol|phb} (a gift to you when you entered the priesthood), a prayer book, 5 sticks of incense, and a set of {@item common clothes|phb}.

entries.name: Feature: Shelter of the Faithful
entries: As an acolyte, you command the respect of those who share your faith, and you can perform the religious ceremonies of your deity. You and your adventuring companions can expect to receive free healing and care at a temple, shrine, or other established presence of your faith, though you must provide any material components needed for spells. Those who share your religion will support you (but only you) at a modest lifestyle.

You might also have ties to a specific temple dedicated to your chosen deity or pantheon, and you have a residence there. This could be the temple where you used to serve, if you remain on good terms with it, or a temple where you have found a new home. While near your temple, you can call upon the priests for assistance, provided the assistance you ask for is not hazardous and you remain in good standing with your temple.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Acolytes are shaped by their experience in temples or other religious communities. Their study of the history and tenets of their faith and their relationships to temples, shrines, or hierarchies affect their mannerisms and ideals. Their flaws might be some hidden hypocrisy or heretical idea, or an ideal or bond taken to an extreme.

rows: I idolize a particular hero of my faith, and constantly refer to that person's deeds and example.
I can find common ground between the fiercest enemies, empathizing with them and always working toward peace.
I see omens in every event and action. The gods try to speak to us, we just need to listen.
Nothing can shake my optimistic attitude.
I quote (or misquote) sacred texts and proverbs in almost every situation.
I am tolerant (or intolerant) of other faiths and respect (or condemn) the worship of other gods.
I've enjoyed fine food, drink, and high society among my temple's elite. Rough living grates on me.
I've spent so long in the temple that I have little practical experience dealing with people in the outside world.
Tradition. The ancient traditions of worship and sacrifice must be preserved and upheld. (Lawful)
Charity. I always try to help those in need, no matter what the personal cost. (Good)
Change. We must help bring about the changes the gods are constantly working in the world. (Chaotic)
Power. I hope to one day rise to the top of my faith's religious hierarchy. (Lawful)
Faith. I trust that my deity will guide my actions. I have faith that if I work hard, things will go well. (Lawful)
Aspiration. I seek to prove myself worthy of my god's favor by matching my actions against his or her teachings. (Any)
I would die to recover an ancient relic of my faith that was lost long ago.
I will someday get revenge on the corrupt temple hierarchy who branded me a heretic.
I owe my life to the priest who took me in when my parents died.
Everything I do is for the common people.
I will do anything to protect the temple where I served.
I seek to preserve a sacred text that my enemies consider heretical and seek to destroy.
I judge others harshly, and myself even more severely.
I put too much trust in those who wield power within my temple's hierarchy.
My piety sometimes leads me to blindly trust those that profess faith in my god.
I am inflexible in my thinking.
I am suspicious of strangers and expect the worst of them.
Once I pick a goal, I become obsessed with it to the detriment of everything else in my life.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Insight}, {@skill Religion}

items.name: Tool Proficiency
items.entry: Choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: Two of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a leather-bound diary, a bottle of ink, an ink pen, and a set of {@item traveler's clothes|phb}.

entries.name: Cultural Chameleon
entries: Before becoming an adventurer, you spent much of your adult life away from your homeland, living among people different from your kin. You came to understand these foreign cultures and the ways of their people, who eventually treated you as one of their own. One culture had more of an influence on you than any other, shaping your beliefs and customs Choose a race whose culture you've adopted, or roll on the Adopted Culture table.

rows: Aarakocra
Dwarf
Elf
Goblin
Halfling
Human
Lizardfolk
Orc

entries.name: Feature: Adept Linguist
entries: You can communicate with humanoids who don't speak any language you know. You must observe the humanoids interacting with one another for at least 1 day, after which you learn a handful of important words, expressions, and gestures - enough to communicate on a rudimentary level.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Anthropologists leave behind the societies into which they were born to discover what life is like in other parts of the world. They seek to see how other races and civilizations survive - or why they did not. Some anthropologists are driven by intellectual curiosity, while others want the fame and recognition that comes with being the first to discover a new people, a lost tribe, or the truth about an ancient empire's downfall.

rows: I prefer the company of those who aren't like me, including people of other races
I'm a stickler when it comes to observing proper etiquette and local customs
I would rather observe than meddle
By living among violent people, I have become desensitized to violence.
I would risk life and limb to discover a new culture or unravel the secrets of a dead one.
When I arrive at a new settlement for the first time, I must learn all its customs.
Discovery. I want to be the first person to discover a lost culture. (Any)
Distance. One must not interfere with the affairs of another culture - even one in need of aid. (Lawful)
Knowledge. By understanding other races and cultures, we learn to understand ourselves. (Any)
Power. Common people crave strong leadership, and I do my utmost to provide it. (Lawful)
Protection. I must do everything possible to save a society facing extinction. (Good)
Indifferent. Life is cruel. What's the point in saving people if they're going to die anyway? (Chaotic)
My mentor gave me a journal filled with lore and wisdom. Losing it would devastate me.
Having lived among the people of a primeval tribe or clan, I long to return and see how they are faring.
Years ago, tragedy struck the members of an isolated society I befriended, and I will honor them.
I want to learn more about a particular humanoid culture that fascinates me.
I seek to avenge a clan, tribe, kingdom, or empire that was wiped out.
I have a trinket that I believe is the key to finding a long-lost society.
Boats make me seasick.
I talk to myself, and I don't make friends easily.
I believe that I'm intellectually superior to people from other cultures and have much to teach them.
I've picked up some unpleasant habits living among goblins, lizardfolk, or orcs.
I complain about everything.
I wear a tribal mask and never take it off.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill History}, {@skill Survival}

items.name: Tool Proficiency
items.entry: Choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a {@item miner's pick|phb}, a set of {@item traveler's clothes|phb}, a {@item shovel|phb}, a {@item crowbar|phb}, and a hat.

entries.name: Feature: Historical Knowledge
entries: When you enter a ruin or dungeon, you can correctly ascertain its original purpose and determine its builders, whether those were dwarves, elves, humans, yuan-ti, or some other known race. In addition, you can determine the monetary value of art objects more than a century old.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Few archaeologists can resist the lure of an unexplored ruin or dungeon, particularly if such a site is the source of legends or is rumored to contain the treasures and relics of wizards, warlords, or royalty. Some archaeologists plunder for wealth or fame, while others consider it their calling to illuminate the past or keep the world's greatest treasures from falling into the wrong hands. Whatever their motivations, archaeologists combine the qualities of a scrappy historian with the self-made heroism of a treasure-hunting scoundrel.

rows: I love a good puzzle or mystery
I'm a pack rat who never throws anything away.
Fame is more important to me than money.
I have no qualms about stealing from the dead.
I'm happier in a dusty old tomb than I am in the centers of civilization.
Traps don't make me nervous. Idiots who trigger traps make me nervous.
I might fail, but I will never give up.
You might think I'm a scholar, but I love a good brawl. These fists were made for punching.
Preservation. That artifact belongs in a museum. (Good)
Greed. I won't risk my life for nothing. I expect some kind of payment. (Any)
Death Wish. Nothing is more exhilarating than a narrow escape from the jaws of death. (Chaotic)
Dignity. The dead and their belongings deserve to be treated with respect. (Lawful)
Immortality. All of my exploring is part of a plan to find the secret of everlasting life. (Any)
Danger. With every great discovery comes grave danger. The two walk hand in hand. (Any)
Ever since I was a child, I've heard stories about a lost city. I aim to find it, learn its secrets, and earn my place in the history books.
I want to find my mentor, who disappeared on an expedition some time ago.
I have a friendly rival. Only one of us can be the best, and I aim to prove it's me.
I won't sell an art object or other treasure that has historical significance or is one of a kind.
I'm secretly in love with the wealthy patron who sponsors my archaeological exploits.
I hope to bring prestige to a library, a museum, or a university.
I have a secret fear of some common wild animal - and in my work, I see them everywhere.
I can't leave a room without searching it for secret doors.
When I'm not exploring dungeons or ruins. I get jittery and impatient.
I have no time for friends or family. I spend every waking moment thinking about and preparing for my next expedition.
When given the choice of going left or right, I always go left.
I can't sleep except in total darkness.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Animal Handling}, {@skill Survival}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: {@filter Vehicles (land)|items|source=phb;dmg|miscellaneous=mundane|type=vehicle (land)}. Choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}.

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a {@item whip|phb}, a {@item two-person tent|phb}, and a set of {@item traveler's clothes|phb}.

entries.name: Lifestyle
entries: Poor

entries.name: Overview
entries: You are used to life on the road. You pride yourself at having traveled every major trade way in the Moonsea region, including the best backroads and shortcuts. When traveling these roads, you know where the best inns, campsites, and water sources are located, as well as potential locations of danger such as ambush. Having worked the roads as long as you have, you have made many acquaintances and find it easy to pick up information and rumors floating from town to town. You are skilled with beasts of burden and handling and repairing wagons of all kinds.

entries.name: Feature: Wagonmaster
entries: You are used to being in charge of the operation and your reputation for reliability has you on a short list when the job is critical. Experience has taught you to rely on your gut. Others recognize this and look to you for direction when a situation gets serious. You are able to identify the most defensible locations for camping. If you are part of a caravan outfit, you are able to attract two additional workers that are loyal to you based on your reputation. You have an excellent memory for maps and geography and can always determine your cardinal directions while traveling. Note: This feature is a variant of the Outlander feature.

rows: Any group is only as strong as its weakest link. Everyone has to pull their own weight.
There's always someone out there trying to take what I've got. Always be vigilant.
Anything can be learned if you have the right teacher. Most folks just need a chance.
Early to bed and early to rise; this much at least is under my control.
You can listen to me or don't and wish you had. Everyone ends up on one side of that fence.
Eventually my hard work will be rewarded. Maybe that time has finally come.
A strong ox or horse is more reliable than most people I've met.
I never had time for books, but wish I had. I admire folks who have taken the time to learn.
Service. Using my talents to help others is the best way of helping myself. (Good)
Selfish. What people don't know WILL hurt them, but why is that my problem? (Evil)
Wanderer. I go where the road takes me. Sometimes that's a good thing... (Chaotic)
Fittest. On the open road, the law of nature wins. Victims are the unprepared. (Lawful)
Focused. I simply have a job to do, and I'm going to do it. (Neutral)
Motivated. There's a reason I'm good at what I do, I pay attention to the details. (Any)
My brother has a farm In Elmwood and I've helped him and his neighbors move their goods to Mulmaster and other surrounding towns. Those are good people.
A caravan I lead was attacked by bandits and many innocents died. I swear that I will avenge them by killing any bandits I encounter.
The Soldiery are mostly good guys who understand the importance of protecting the roads. The City Watch is who you have to look out for. If they are inspecting your goods, get ready to pay a fine.
The new commander of Southroad Tower, Capt. Holke, understands the importance of safe roads. He's hired me for several jobs and I'm grateful.
There's always a road I haven't traveled before. I'm always looking for new places to explore.
Wealth and power mean little without the freedom to go where and when you want.
I have trouble trusting people I've just met.
I enjoy the open road. Underground and tight spaces make me very nervous.
I expect others to heed my orders and have little respect or sympathy if they don't.
I am very prideful and have trouble admitting when I'm wrong.
Once I decide on a course of action, I do not waiver.
I like to explore, and my curiosity will sometimes get me into trouble.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Deception}, {@skill Sleight of Hand}

items.name: Tool Proficiency
items.entry: One type of {@filter musical instrument|items|source=phb|miscellaneous=mundane|type=instrument}. Choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: Any one of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a set of {@item fine clothes|phb}, tools of the con of your choice (ten stoppered bottles filled with colored liquid, a set of weighted dice,or a deck of marked cards).

entries.name: Feature: False Identity
entries: You have created a second identity that includes documentation, established acquaintances, and disguises that allow you to assume that persona. Additionally, you can forge documents including official papers and personal letters, as long as you have seen an example of the kind of document or the handwriting you are trying to copy.

entries.name: Favorite Schemes
entries: Every charlatan has an angle he or she uses in preference to other schemes. Choose a favorite scam or roll on the table below.

rows: I cheat at games of chance.
I shave coins or forge documents.
I insinuate myself into people's lives to prey on their weakness and secure their fortunes.
I put on new identities like clothes.
I run sleight-of-hand cons on street corners.
I convince people that worthless junk is worth their hard-earned money.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Charlatans are colorful characters who conceal their true selves behind the masks they construct. They reflect what people want to see, what they want to believe, and how they see the world. But their true selves are sometimes plagued by an uneasy conscience, an old enemy, or deep-seated trust issues.

rows: I fall in and out of love easily, and am always pursuing someone.
I have a joke for every occasion, especially occasions where humor is inappropriate.
Flattery is my preferred trick for getting what I want.
I'm a born gambler who can't resist taking a risk for a potential payoff.
I lie about almost everything, even when there's no reason to.
Sarcasm and insults are my weapons of choice.
I keep multiple holy symbols on me and invoke whatever deity might come in useful at any given moment.
I pocket anything I see that might have some value.
Independence. I am a free spirit—no one tells me what to do. (Chaotic)
Fairness. I never target people who can't afford to lose a few coins. (Lawful)
Charity. I distribute the money I acquire to the people who really need it. (Good)
Creativity. I never run the same con twice. (Chaotic)
Friendship. Material goods come and go. Bonds of friendship last forever. (Good)
Aspiration. I'm determined to make something of myself. (Any)
I fleeced the wrong person and must work to ensure that this individual never crosses paths with me or those I care about.
I owe everything to my mentor—a horrible person who's probably rotting in jail somewhere.
Somewhere out there, I have a child who doesn't know me. I'm making the world better for him or her.
I come from a noble family, and one day I'll reclaim my lands and title from those who stole them from me.
A powerful person killed someone I love. Some day soon, I'll have my revenge.
I swindled and ruined a person who didn't deserve it. I seek to atone for my misdeeds but might never be able to forgive myself.
I can't resist a pretty face.
I'm always in debt. I spend my ill-gotten gains on decadent luxuries faster than I bring them in.
I'm convinced that no one could ever fool me the way I fool others.
I'm too greedy for my own good. I can't resist taking a risk if there's money involved.
I can't resist swindling people who are more powerful than me.
I hate to admit it and will hate myself for it, but I'll run and preserve my own hide if the going gets tough.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Athletics}, {@skill Insight}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: Any two of your choice

items.name: Tool Proficiency
items.entry: Choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a uniform in the style of your unit and indicative of your rank, a {@item horn|phb}, a set of {@item manacles|phb}.

entries.name: Feature: Watcher's Eye
entries: Your experience in enforcing the law, and dealing with lawbreakers, gives you a feel for local laws and criminals. You can easily find the local outpost of the watch or a similar organization, and just as easily pick out the dens of criminal activity in a community, although you're more likely to be welcome in the former locations rather than the latter.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Use the tables for the {@background soldier} background in the Player's Handbook as the basis for your traits and motivations, modifying the entries when appropriate to suit your identity as a member of the city watch.

Your bond is likely associated with your fellow watch members or the watch organization itself and almost certainly concerns your community. Your ideal probably involves the fostering of peace and safety. An investigator is likely to have an ideal connected to achieving justice by successfully solving crimes.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill History}, {@skill Insight}

items.name: Tool Proficiency
