items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a uniform of your company ({@item traveler's clothes|phb} in quality), and a belt with a {@item pouch|phb} and sheath (if appropriate).

entries.name: Feature: Mercenary Life
entries: You know the mercenary life as only someone who has experienced it can. You are able to identify mercenary companies by their emblems, and you know a little about any such company, including who has hired them recently. You can find the taverns and festhalls where mercenaries abide in any area, as long as you speak the language. You can find mercenary work between adventures sufficient to maintain a comfortable lifestyle (see "Practicing a Profession" under "Downtime Activities" in chapter 8 of the Player's Handbook).

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Use the tables for the {@background soldier} background in the Player's Handbook as the basis for your traits and motivations, modifying the entries when appropriate to suit your identity as a mercenary.

Your bond could be associated with the company you traveled with previously, or with some of the comrades you served with. The ideal you embrace largely depends on your worldview and your motivation for fighting.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill History}, {@skill Persuasion}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: Choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a set of {@item fine clothes|phb}, and a {@item signet ring|phb} (5gp value)

entries.name: Feature: Position of Privilege
entries: Thanks to your noble birth, people are inclined to think the best of you. You are welcome in high society, and people assume you have the right to be wherever you are. The common folk make every effort to accommodate you and avoid your displeasure, and other people of high birth treat you as a member of the same social sphere. You can secure an audience with a local noble if you need to.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Nobles are born and raised to a very different lifestyle than most people ever experience, and their personalities reflect that upbringing. A noble title comes with a plethora of bonds—responsibilities to family, to other nobles (including the sovereign), to the people entrusted to the family's care, or even to the title itself. But this responsibility is often a good way to undermine a noble.

rows: My eloquent flattery makes everyone I talk to feel like the most wonderful and important person in the world.
The common folk love me for my kindness and generosity.
No one could doubt by looking at my regal bearing that I am a cut above the unwashed masses.
I take great pains to always look my best and follow the latest fashions.
I don't like to get my hands dirty, and I won't be caught dead in unsuitable accommodations.
Despite my noble birth, I do not place myself above other folk. We all have the same blood.
My favor, once lost, is lost forever.
If you do me an injury, I will crush you, ruin your name, and salt your fields.
Respect. Respect is due to me because of my position, but all people regardless of station deserve to be treated with dignity. (Good)
Responsibility. It is my duty to respect the authority of those above me, just as those below me must respect mine. (Lawful)
Independence. I must prove that I can handle myself without coddling from my family. (Chaotic)
Power. If I can attain more power, no one will tell me what to do. (Evil)
Family. Blood runs thicker than water. (Any)
Noble Obligation. It is my duty to protect and care for the people beneath me. (Good)
I will face any challenge to win the approval of my family.
My house's alliance with another noble family must be sustained at all costs.
Nothing is more important than the other members of my family.
I am in love with the heir of a family that my family despises.
My loyalty to my sovereign is unwavering.
The common folk must see me as a hero of the people.
I secretly believe that everyone is beneath me.
I hide a truly scandalous secret that could ruin my family forever.
I too often hear veiled insults and threats in every word addressed to me, and I'm quick to anger.
I have an insatiable desire for carnal pleasures.
In fact, the world does revolve around me.
By my words and actions, I often bring shame to my family.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Athletics}, {@skill Survival}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: One type of {@filter musical instrument|items|source=phb|miscellaneous=mundane|type=instrument} and choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a trophy from an animal you killed, a set of {@item traveler's clothes|phb}, and a water resistant cloak.

entries.name: Feature: Wanderer
entries: You have an excellent memory for maps and geography, and you can always recall the general layout of terrain, settlements, and other features around you. In addition, you can find food and fresh water for yourself and up to five other people each day, provided that the land offers berries, small game, water, and so forth.

entries.name: Specialty
entries: You've been to strange places and seen things that others cannot begin to fathom. Consider some of the distant lands you have visited, and how they impacted you. You can roll on the following table to determine your occupation during your time in the wild, or choose one that best fits your character.

rows: Forester
Trapper
Homesteader
Guide
Exile or outcast
Bounty hunter
Pilgrim
Tribal nomad
Hunter-gatherer
Tribal marauder

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Often considered rude and uncouth among civilized folk, outlanders have little respect for the niceties of life in the cities. The ties of tribe, clan, family, and the natural world of which they are a part are the most important bonds to most outlanders.

rows: I'm driven by a wanderlust that led me away from home
I watch over my friends as if they were a litter of newborn pups.
I once ran twenty-five miles without stopping to warn to my clan of an approaching orc horde. I'd do it again if I had to.
I have a lesson for every situation, drawn from observing nature.
I place no stock in wealthy or well-mannered folk. Money and manners won't save you from a hungry owlbear.
I'm always picking things up, absently fiddling with them, and sometimes accidentally breaking them.
I feel far more comfortable around animals than people
I was, in fact, raised by wolves.
Change. Life is like the seasons, in constant change, and we must change with it. (Chaotic)
Greater Good. It is each person's responsibility to make the most happiness for the whole tribe. (Good)
Honor. If I dishonor myself, I dishonor my whole clan. (Lawful)
Might. The strongest are meant to rule. (Evil)
Nature. The natural world is more important than all the constructs of civilization. (Neutral)
Glory. I must earn glory in battle, for myself and my clan. (Any)
My family, clan, or tribe is the most important thing in my life, even when they are far from me.
An injury to the unspoiled wilderness of my home is an injury to me.
I will bring terrible wrath down on the evildoers who destroyed my homeland.
I am the last of my tribe, and it is up to me to ensure their names enter legend.
I suffer awful visions of a coming disaster and will do anything to prevent it.
It is my duty to provide children to sustain my tribe.
I am too enamored of ale, wine, and other intoxicants.
There's no room for caution in a life lived to the fullest.
I remember every insult I've received and nurse a silent resentment toward anyone who's ever wronged me.
I am slow to trust members of other races, tribes, and societies.
Violence is my answer to almost any challenge.
Don't expect me to save those who can't save themselves. It is nature's way that the strong thrive and the weak perish.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Arcana}, {@skill History}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: Two of your choice

items.name: Tool Proficiency
items.entry: Choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a bottle of black ink, a quill, and a set of {@item common clothes|phb}

entries.name: Feature: Researcher
entries: When you attempt to learn or recall a piece of lore, if you do not know that information, you often know where and from whom you can obtain it. Usually, this information comes from a library, scriptorium, university, or a sage or other learned person or creature, Your DM might rule that the knowledge you seek is secreted away in an almost inaccessible place, or that it simply cannot be found. Unearthing the deepest secrets of the multiverse can require an adventure or even a whole campaign.

entries.name: Specialty
entries: To determine the nature of your scholarly training, roll a d8 or choose from the options in the table below.

rows: Alchemist
Astronomer
Discredited academic
Librarian
Professor
Researcher
Wizard's apprentice
Scribe

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Sages are defined by their extensive studies, and their characteristics reflect this life of study. Devoted to scholarly pursuits, a sage values knowledge highly—sometimes in its own right, sometimes as a means toward other ideals.

rows: I use polysyllabic words that convey the impression of great erudition.
I've read every book in the world's greatest libraries—or I like to boast that I have.
I'm used to helping out those who aren't as smart as I am, and I patiently explain anything and everything to others.
There's nothing I like more than a good mystery.
I'm willing to listen to every side of an argument before I make my own judgment.
I . . . speak . . . slowly . . . when talking . . . to idiots, . . . which . . . almost . . . everyone . . . is . . . compared . . . to me.
I am horribly, horribly awkward in social situations.
I'm convinced that people are always trying to steal my secrets.
Knowledge. The path to power and self-improvement is through knowledge. (Neutral)
Beauty. What is beautiful points us beyond itself toward what is true. (Good)
Logic. Emotions must not cloud our logical thinking. (Lawful)
No Limits. Nothing should fetter the infinite possibility inherent in all existence. (Chaotic)
Power. Knowledge is the path to power and domination. (Evil)
Self-Improvement. The goal of a life of study is the betterment of oneself. (Any)
It is my duty to protect my students.
I have an ancient text that holds terrible secrets that must not fall into the wrong hands.
I work to preserve a library, university, scriptorium, or monastery.
My life's work is a series of tomes related to a specific field of lore.
I've been searching my whole life for the answer to a certain question.
I sold my soul for knowledge. I hope to do great deeds and win it back.
I am easily distracted by the promise of information.
Most people scream and run when they see a demon. I stop and take notes on its anatomy.
Unlocking an ancient mystery is worth the price of a civilization.
I overlook obvious solutions in favor of complicated ones.
I speak without really thinking through my words, invariably insulting others.
I can't keep a secret to save my life, or anyone else's.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Athletics}, {@skill Perception}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: {@filter vehicles (water)|items|source=phb;dmg|miscellaneous=mundane|type=vehicle (water)}, and choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a belaying pin ({@item club|phb}), {@item silk rope (50 feet)|phb}, and a set of {@item common clothes|phb}

entries.name: Feature: Ship's Passage
entries: When you need to, you can secure free passage on a sailing ship for yourself and your adventuring companions. You might sail on the ship you served on, or another ship you have good relations with (perhaps one captained by a former crewmate). Because you're calling in a favor, you can't be certain of a schedule or route that will meet your every need. Your Dungeon Master will determine how long it takes to get where you need to go. In return for your free passage, you and your companions are expected to assist the crew during the voyage.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Sailors can be a rough lot, but the responsibilities of life on a ship make them generally reliable as well. Life aboard a ship shapes their outlook and forms their most important attachments.

rows: My friends know they can rely on me, no matter what.
I work hard so that I can play hard when the work is done.
I enjoy sailing into new ports and making new friends over a flagon of ale.
I stretch the truth for the sake of a good story.
To me, a tavern brawl is a nice way to get to know a new city.
I never pass up a friendly wager.
My language is as foul as an otyugh nest.
I like a job well done, especially if I can convince someone else to do it.
Respect. The thing that keeps a ship together is mutual respect between captain and crew. (Good)
Fairness. We all do the work, so we all share in the rewards. (Lawful)
Freedom. The sea is freedom—the freedom to go anywhere and do anything. (Chaotic)
Mastery. I'm a predator, and the other ships on the sea are my prey. (Evil)
People. I'm committed to my crewmates, not to ideals. (Neutral)
Aspiration. Someday, I'll own my own ship and chart my own destiny. (Any)
I'm loyal to my captain first, everything else second.
The ship is most important—crewmates and captains come and go.
I'll always remember my first ship.
In a harbor town, I have a paramour whose eyes nearly stole me from the sea.
I was cheated out of my fair share of the profits, and I want to get my due.
Ruthless pirates murdered my captain and crewmates, plundered our ship, and left me lo die. Vengeance will be mine.
I follow orders, even if I think they're wrong.
I'll say anything to avoid having to do extra work.
Once someone questions my courage, I never back down no matter how dangerous the situation.
Once I start drinking, it's hard for me to stop.
I can't help but pocket loose coins and other trinkets I come across.
My pride will probably lead to my destruction.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Athletics}, {@skill Intimidation}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: {@filter vehicles (land)|items|source=phb;dmg|miscellaneous=mundane|type=vehicle (land)} and choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, an insignia of rank, a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, a belt with a {@item pouch|phb} and sheath, a {@item bedroll|phb}, and {@item backpack|phb}

entries.name: Feature: Military Rank
entries: You have a military rank from your career as a soldier. Soldiers loyal to your former military organization still recognize your authority and influence, and they defer to you if they are of a lower rank. You can invoke your rank to exert influence over other soldiers and requisition simple equipment or horses for temporary use. You can also usually gain access to friendly military encampments and fortresses where your rank is recognized.

entries.name: Specialty
entries: During your time as a soldier, you had a specific role to play in your unit or army. Roll a d8 or choose from the options in the table below to determine your role:

rows: Officer
Scout
Infantry
Cavalry
Healer
Quartermaster
Standard-bearer
Support staff (cook, blacksmith, or the like)

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: The horrors of war combined with the rigid discipline of military service leave their mark on all soldiers, shaping their ideals, creating strong bonds, and often leaving them scarred and vulnerable to fear, shame, and hatred.

rows: I'm always polite and respectful.
I'm haunted by memories of war. I can't get the images of violence out of my mind.
I've lost too many friends, and I'm slow to make new ones.
I'm full of inspiring and cautionary tales from my military experience relevant to almost every combat situation.
I can stare down a hell hound without flinching.
I enjoy being strong and like breaking things.
I have a crude sense of humor.
I face problems head-on. A simple, direct solution is the best path to success.
Greater Good. Our lot is to lay down our lives in defense of others. (Good)
Responsibility. I do what I must and obey just authority. (Lawful)
Independence. When people follow orders blindly, they embrace a kind of tyranny. (Chaotic)
Might. In life as in war, the stronger force wins. (Evil)
Live and Let Live. Ideals aren't worth killing over or going to war for. (Neutral)
Nation. My city, nation, or people are all that matter. (Any)
I would still lay down my life for the people I served with.
Someone saved my life on the battlefield. To this day, I will never leave a friend behind.
My honor is my life.
I'll never forget the crushing defeat my company suffered or the enemies who dealt it.
Those who fight beside me are those worth dying for.
I fight for those who cannot fight for themselves.
The monstrous enemy we faced in battle still leaves me quivering with fear.
I have little respect for anyone who is not a proven warrior.
I made a terrible mistake in battle that cost many lives—and I would do anything to keep that mistake secret.
My hatred of my enemies is blinding and unreasoning.
I obey the law, even if the law causes misery.
I'd rather eat my armor than admit when I'm wrong.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Sleight of Hand}, {@skill Stealth}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: Choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a set of {@item common clothes|phb} with hidden {@item pouch|phb}es

entries.name: Feature: City Secrets
entries: You know the secret patterns and flow to cities and can find passages through the urban sprawl that others would miss. When you are not in combat, you (and companions you lead) can travel between any two locations in the city twice as fast as your speed would normally allow.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Urchins are shaped by lives of desperate poverty, for good and for ill. They tend to be driven either by a commitment to the people with whom they shared life on the street or by a burning desire to find a better life—and maybe get some payback on all the rich people who treated them badly.

rows: I hide scraps of food and trinkets away in my pockets.
I ask a lot of questions.
I like to squeeze into small places where no one else can get to me.
I sleep with my back to a wall or tree, with everything I own wrapped in a bundle in my arms.
I eat like a pig and have bad manners.
I think anyone who's nice to me is hiding evil intent.
I don't like to bathe.
I bluntly say what others are hinting at or hiding.
Respect. All people, rich or poor, deserve respect. (Good)
Community. We have to take care of each other, because no one else is going to do it. (Lawful)
Change. The low are lifted up, and the high and mighty are brought down. Change is the nature of things. (Chaotic)
Retribution. The rich need to be shown what life and death are like in the gutters. (Evil)
People. I help the people who help me—that's what keeps us alive. (Neutral)
Aspiration. I'm going to prove that I'm worthy of a better life. (Any)
My town is my city or my home, and I'll fight to defend it.
I sponsor an orphanage to keep others from enduring what I was forced to endure.
I owe my survival to another urchin who taught me to live on the streets.
I owe a debt I can never repay to the person who took pity on me.
I escaped my life of poverty by robbing an important person, and I'm wanted for it.
No one else should have to endure the hardships I've been through.
If I'm outnumbered, I will run away from a fight.
Gold seems like a lot of money to me, and I'll do just about anything for more of it.
I will never fully trust anyone other than myself.
I'd rather kill someone in their sleep than fight fair.
It's not stealing if I need it more than someone else.
People who can't take care of themselves get what they deserve.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Insight}, {@skill Investigation}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: Any two of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a uniform in the style of your unit and indicative of your rank, a {@item horn|phb}, a set of {@item manacles|phb}.

entries.name: Feature: Watcher's Eye
entries: Your experience in enforcing the law, and dealing with lawbreakers, gives you a feel for local laws and criminals. You can easily find the local outpost of the watch or a similar organization, and just as easily pick out the dens of criminal activity in a community, although you're more likely to be welcome in the former locations rather than the latter.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Use the tables for the {@background soldier} background in the Player's Handbook as the basis for your traits and motivations, modifying the entries when appropriate to suit your identity as a member of the city watch.

Your bond is likely associated with your fellow watch members or the watch organization itself and almost certainly concerns your community. Your ideal probably involves the fostering of peace and safety. An investigator is likely to have an ideal connected to achieving justice by successfully solving crimes.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Athletics}, {@skill Perception}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: {@filter vehicles (water)|items|source=phb;dmg|miscellaneous=mundane|type=vehicle (water)}, and choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a belaying pin ({@item club|phb}), {@item silk rope (50 feet)|phb}, and a set of {@item common clothes|phb}

entries.name: Feature: Bad Reputation
entries: No matter where you go, people are afraid of you due to your reputation. When you are in a civilized settlement, you can get away with minor criminal offenses, such as refusing to pay for food at a tavern or breaking down doors at a local shop, since most people will not report your activity to the authorities.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill History}, {@skill Survival}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Tool Proficiency
items.entry: One type of {@filter musical instrument|items|source=phb|miscellaneous=mundane|type=instrument} and choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, fishing tackle, a {@item net|phb}, wading boots, a set of fish stained {@item traveler's clothes|phb}, and a belt

entries.name: Feature: Harvest the Water
entries: You gain advantage on ability checks made using fishing tackle. If you have access to a body of water that sustains marine life, you can maintain a moderate lifestyle while working as a fisher, and you can catch enough food to feed yourself and up to ten other people each day.

entries.name: Fishing Tale
entries: You can tell a compelling tale, whether tall or true, to impress and entertain others. Once a day, you can tell your story to willing listeners. At the DM's discretion, a number of those listeners become friendly toward you; this is not a magical effect, and continued amicability on their part depends on your actions. You can roll on the following table to help determine the theme of your tale or choose one that best fits your character. Alternatively, work with your DM to create your own fishing tale.

rows: Lobster Wrestling. You fought in hand-to-hand combat with an immense lobster.
It Dragged the Boat. You nearly caught a fish of monstrous size that pulled your boat for miles.
Fins of Pure Gold. You caught a sea animal whose fins were made of pure gold, but another fisher stole it.
Ghost Fish. You are haunted by a ghostly fish that only you can see.
Nemesis Clam. A large clam containing a pearl the size of your head claimed one of your fingers before jetting away; one day, you'll find that clam.
It Swallowed the Sun. You once saw a fish leap from the water and turn day into night.
Dive into the Abyss. You found yourself in an underwater cave leading to the Abyss, and your luck has been sour ever since.
Love Story. You fell in love with a creature of pure water, but your brief romance ended tragically.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Fishers succeed only if they spend time at their jobs. As such, most fishers have a strong work ethic, and they admire others who earn their living honestly. Fishers tend to be superstitious, forming attachments to particular fishing lures or special fishing spots. They have a connection to the bodies of water in which they fish, and they think poorly of those whose actions adversely affect their livelihood.

entries.caption: Fisher Personality Traits
rows: I am unmoved by the wrath of nature.
My friends are my crew; we sink or float together.
I need long stretches of quiet to clear my head.
Rich folk don't know the satisfaction of hard work.
I laugh heartily, feel deeply, and fear nothing.
I work hard; nature offers no handouts.
I dislike bargaining; state your price and mean it.
Luck favors me, and I take risks others might not.

entries.caption: Fisher Ideals
rows: {@b Camaraderie.} Good people make even the longest voyage bearable. (Good)
{@b Luck.} Our luck depends on respecting its rules—now throw this salt over your shoulder. (Lawful)
{@b Daring.} The richest bounty goes to those who risk everything. (Chaotic)
{@b Plunder.} Take all that you can and leave nothing for the scavengers. (Evil)
{@b Balance.} Do not fish the same spot twice in a row; suppress your greed, and nature will reward you. (Neutral)
{@b Hard Work.} No wave can move a soul hard at work. (Any)

entries.caption: Fisher Bonds
rows: I lost something important in the deep sea, and I intend to find it.
Someone else's greed destroyed my livelihood, and I will be compensated.
I will fish the many famous waters of this land.
The gods saved me during a terrible storm, and I will honor their gift.
My destiny awaits me at the bottom of a particular pond in the Feywild.
I must repay my village's debt.

entries.caption: Fisher Flaws
rows: I am judgmental, especially of those I deem homebodies or otherwise lazy.
I become depressed and anxious if I'm away from the sea too long.
I have lived a hard life and find it difficult to empathize with others.
I am inclined to tell long-winded stories at inopportune times.
I work hard, but I play harder.
I am obsessed with catching an elusive aquatic beast, often to the detriment of other pursuits.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Athletics}, {@skill Survival}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: {@filter Vehicles (water, land)|items|source=phb;dmg|miscellaneous=mundane|type=vehicle (land);vehicle (water)}, {@filter Vehicles (water, land)|items|source=phb;dmg|miscellaneous=mundane|type=vehicle (land);vehicle (water)}. Choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a {@item dagger|phb}, a folded flag emblazoned with the symbol of your ship, a set of {@item traveler's clothes|phb}, and a belt {@item pouch|phb}

entries.name: Feature: Steady
entries: You can move twice the normal amount of time (up to 16 hours) each day before being subject to the effect of a forced march (see "Travel Pace" in chapter 8 of the Player's Handbook). Additionally, you can automatically find a safe route to land a boat on shore, provided such a route exists.

entries.name: Hardship Endured
entries: Hardship in your past has forged you into an unstoppable living weapon. This hardship is essential to you and is at the heart of a personal philosophy or ethos that often guides your actions. You can roll on the following table to determine this hardship or choose one that best fits your character.

rows: Nearly Drowned. You hid underwater to avoid detection by enemies and held your breath for an extremely long time. Just before you would have died, you had a revelation about your existence.
Captured. You spent months enduring thirst, starvation, and torture at the hands of your enemy, but you never broke.
Sacrifice. You enabled the escape of your fellow soldiers, but at great cost to yourself. Some of your past comrades may think you're dead.
Juggernaut. No reasonable explanation can explain how you survived a particular battle. Every arrow and bolt missed you. You slew scores of enemies single-handedly and led your comrades to victory.
Stowaway. For days, you hid in the bilge of an enemy ship, surviving on brackish water and foolhardy rats. At the right moment, you crept up to the deck and took over the ship on your own.
Leave None Behind. You carried an injured marine for miles to avoid capture and death.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Marines are looked up to by other soldiers and respected by their superiors. They are veteran warriors who rarely lose composure on the battlefield. Marines who leave the service tend to work as mercenaries, but their combat experience also makes them excellent adventurers. Though they are self-reliant, marines tend to operate best in groups, valuing camaraderie and the companionship of like-minded individuals.

entries.caption: Marine Personality Traits
rows: I speak rarely but mean every word I say.
I laugh loudly and see the humor in stressful situations.
I prefer to solve problems without violence, but I finish fights decisively.
I enjoy being out in nature; poor weather never sours my mood.
I am dependable.
I am always working on some project or other.
I become cantankerous and quiet in the rain.
When the sea is within my sight, my mood is jovial and optimistic.

entries.caption: Marine Ideals
rows: {@b Teamwork.} Success depends on cooperation and communication. (Good)
{@b Code.} The marines' code provides a solution for every problem, and following it is imperative. (Lawful)
{@b Embracing.} Life is messy. Throwing yourself into the worst of it is necessary to get the job done. (Chaotic)
{@b Might.} The strong train so that they might rule those who are weak. (Evil)
{@b Bravery.} To act when others quake in fear—this is the essence of the warrior. (Any)
{@b Perseverance.} No injury or obstacle can turn me from my goal. (Any)

entries.caption: Marine Bonds
rows: I face danger and evil to offset an unredeemable act in my past.
I. Will. Finish. The. Job.
I must set an example of hope for those who have given up.
I'm searching for a fellow marine captured by an elusive enemy.
Fear leads to tyranny, and both must be eradicated.
My commander betrayed my unit, and I will have revenge.

entries.caption: Marine Flaws
rows: I grow combative and unpredictable when I drink.
I find civilian life difficult and struggle to say the right thing in social situations.
My intensity can drive others away.
I hold grudges and have difficulty forgiving others.
I become irrational when innocent people are hurt.
I sometimes stay up all night listening to the ghosts of my fallen enemies.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill History}, {@skill Perception}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: {@filter Vehicles (water)|items|source=phb;dmg|miscellaneous=mundane|type=vehicle (water)} and choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in, a journal with notes on buiilding boats, 1 ounce of ink, an ink pen, a set of {@item traveler's clothes|phb}, and a leather {@item pouch|phb}

entries.name: Feature: I'll Patch It!
entries: Provided you have carpenter's tools and wood, you can perform repairs on a water vehicle. When you use this ability, you restore a number of hit points to the hull of a water vehicle equal to 5 × your proficiency modifier. A vehicle cannot be patched by you in this way again until after it has been pulled ashore and fully repaired.

entries.name: Life at Sea
entries: Your life at sea and in port has shaped you; you can roll on the following table to determine its impact or choose an element that best fits your character.

rows: {@b Grand Designs.} You are working on plans and schematics for a new, very fast ship. You must examine as many different kinds of vessels as possible to help ensure the success of your design.
{@b Solid and Sound.} You patched up a war galley and prevented it from sinking. The local navy regards you as a friend.

{@b Favored.} You insisted on thicker planking for a merchant vessel's hull, which saved it from sinking when it smashed against a reef. You have a standing invitation to visit the merchant's distant mansion.
{@b Master of Armaments.} You specialized in designing and mounting defenses for the navy. You easily recognize and determine the quality of such items.
{@b Low Places.} You have contacts in the smuggling outfits along the coast; you occasionally repair the criminals' ships in exchange for coin and favors.

{@b Mysteries of the Deep.} You experienced an encounter with a possibly divine being while sailing alone. Work with your DM to determine the secret about the deep waters of the sea that this entity revealed to you.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Shipwrights are resourceful carpenters and designers. They often have a dedicated spot at the local tavern, since shipwrights are invaluable to coastal communities. Some travel with naval fleets and might serve as officers if their temperament suits it. Shipwrights have an affinity for working with their hands and often perform feats of carpentry that others might deem miraculous.

entries.caption: Shipwright Personality Traits
rows: I love talking and being heard more than I like to listen.
I'm extremely fond of puzzles.
I thrive under pressure.
I love sketching and designing objects, especially boats.
I'm not afraid of hard work—in fact, I prefer it.
A pipe, an ale, and the smell of the sea: paradise.
I have an endless supply of cautionary tales related to the sea.
I don't mind getting my hands dirty.

entries.caption: Shipwright Ideals
rows: Crew. If everyone on deck pitches in, we'll never sink. (Good)
Careful Lines. A ship must be balanced according to the laws of the universe. (Lawful)
Invention. Make what you need out of whatever is at hand. (Chaotic)
Perfection. To measure a being and find it lacking is the greatest disappointment. (Evil)
Reflection. Muddied water always clears in time. (Any)
Hope. The horizon at sea holds the greatest promise. (Any)

entries.caption: Shipwright Bonds
rows: I must visit all the oceans of the world and behold the ships that sail there.
Much of the treasure I claim will be used to enrich my community.
I must find a kind of wood rumored to possess magical qualities.
I repair broken things to redeem what's broken in myself.
I will craft a boat capable of sailing through the most dangerous of storms.
A kraken destroyed my masterpiece; its teeth shall adorn my hearth.

entries.caption: Shipwright Flaws
rows: I don't know when to throw something away. You never know when it might be useful again.
I get frustrated to the point of distraction by shoddy craftsmanship.
Though I am an excellent crafter, my work tends to look as though it belongs on a ship.
I am so obsessed with sketching my ideas for elaborate inventions that I sometimes forget little thing like eating and sleeping.
I'm judgmental of those who are not skilled with tools of some kind.
I sometimes take things that don't belong to me, especially if they are very well made.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Athletics}, {@skill Deception}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: {@filter Vehicles (water)|items|source=phb;dmg|miscellaneous=mundane|type=vehicle (water)} or {@filter Vehicles (land)|items|source=phb;dmg|miscellaneous=mundane|type=vehicle (land)}. Choose one of {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|phb}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|phb}, {@item Cook's Utensils|phb},  {@item Herbalism Kit|phb}, {@item Jeweler's Tools|phb}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|phb}, {@item Mason's Tools|phb}, {@item Smith's Tools|phb}, or {@item Tinker's Tools|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: Two of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: The toolkit you picked your proficiency in,, a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, and a belt with a {@item pouch|phb}

entries.name: Feature: Down Low
entries: You are acquainted with a network of smugglers who are willing to help you out of tight situations. While in a particular town, city, or other similarly sized community (DM's discretion), you and your companions can stay for free in safe houses. Safe houses provide a poor lifestyle. While staying at a safe house, you can choose to keep your presence (and that of your companions) a secret.

entries.name: Claim to Fame
entries: Every smuggler has that one tale that sets them apart from common criminals. By wits, sailing skill, or a silver tongue, you lived to tell the story—and you tell it often. You can roll on the following table to determine your claim or choose one that best fits your character.

rows: Spirit of the Whale. You smuggled stolen dwarven spirits in the body of a dead whale being pulled behind a fishing boat. When you delivered the goods, the corpse suddenly exploded, sending whale meat and whiskey bottles for half a mile.
Cart and Sword. You drove a cart filled with stolen art through the middle of a battlefield while singing sea shanties to confuse the combatants.
The Recruit. You enlisted in another nation's navy for the purpose of smuggling stolen jewels to a distant port. You attained a minor rank before disappearing from the navy and making your way here.

River of Shadows. Your riverboat accidentally slipped through the veil into the Shadowfell for several hours. While you were there, you sold some stolen dragonborn artifacts before returning to this plane and paddling home.

Gold-Hearted. You agreed to transport a family escaping a war. The baby began to cry at a checkpoint, and you gave the guards all your gold to let you pass. The family never found out about this gesture.

Playing Both Sides. You once smuggled crates of crossbow bolts and bundles of arrows, each destined for an opposing side in a regional war, at the same time. The buyers arrived within moments of each other but did not discover your trickery.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: In general, smugglers value survival, and then profit, above other things. One could be a part of a larger organization, or might run a small smuggling vessel of their own. Smugglers live the lies they have told, and they have a natural ability to recall all the falsehoods and half-truths they have ever spouted.

entries.caption: Smuggler Personality Traits
rows: I love being on the water but hate fishing.
I think of everything in terms of monetary value.
I never stop smiling.
Nothing rattles me; I have a lie for every occasion.
I love gold but won't cheat a friend.
I enjoy doing things others believe to be impossible.
I become wistful when I see the sun rise over the ocean.
I am no common criminal; I am a mastermind.

entries.caption: Smuggler Ideals
rows: {@b Wealth} Heaps of coins in a secure vault is all I dream of. (Any)
{@b Smuggler's Code} I uphold the unwritten rules of the smugglers, who do not cheat one another or directly harm innocents. (Lawful)
{@b All for a Coin} I'll do nearly anything if it means I turn a profit. (Evil)
{@b Peace and Prosperity} I smuggle only to achieve a greater goal that benefits my community. (Good)
{@b People} For all my many lies, I place a high value on friendship. (Any)
{@b Daring} I am most happy when risking everything. (Any)

entries.caption: Smuggler Bonds
rows: My vessel was stolen from me, and I burn with the desire to recover it.
I intend to become the leader of the network of smugglers that I belong to.
I owe a debt that cannot be repaid in gold.
After one last job, I will retire from the business.
I was tricked by a fellow smuggler who stole something precious from me. I will find that thief.
I give most of my profits to a charitable cause, and I don't like to brag about it.

entries.caption: Smuggler Flaws
rows: Lying is reflexive, and I sometimes engage in it without realizing.
I tend to assess my relationships in terms of profit and loss.
I believe everyone has a price and am cynical toward those who present themselves as virtuous.
I struggle to trust the words of others.
Few people know the real me.
Though I act charming, I feel nothing for others and don't know what friendship is.

feat.name: The Memory of Wings
entries: You may manifest magical wings for a short period of time.

items: If you are level 1-9, you may ignore falling damage. The wings manifest just in time to slow your fall and then fade.

If you are level 10 to 20 you gain the above quality and you may use your movement as flight speed as long as at the end of your movement you land. The maximum height you can obtain is equal to your movement. Example: If you move 30 feet you could instead fly 30 feet height, 30 feet forward and then land. If you chose to dash those numbers change to 60 feet.

feat.name: Dwarf Magic
entries: You learn the magic of strength and stone. You learn one cantrip of your choice from the following list: Acid Splash, Blade Ward, Magic Stone, Mending, Primal Savagery, or Thunderclap. You also learn the Earth Tremor and Maximilians Earthen Grasp spells, each of which you can cast once without expending a spell slot. You regain the ability to cast these two spells in this way when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for all three spells.

feat.name: Critter Friend
entries: Your friendship with animals mystically deepens. You gain the following benefits:

items: You gain proficiency in the Animal Handling skill. If you're already proficient in it, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any check you make with it.

You learn the Speak with Animals spell and can cast it at will, without expending a spell slot. You also learn the Animal Friendship spell, and you can cast it once with this feat, without expending a spell slot. You regain the ability to cast it in this way when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

feat.name: Stalwart
entries: Choose one of:

items: Gain proficiency in shields
If you have proficiency in light armour, gain proficiency in medium armour.
If you have proficiency in medium armour, gain proficiency in heavy armour.
Gain a new skill you were not proficient in.
Gain expertise in a skill you possess.

feat.name: Northerner
entries: You gain an additional use of Human Determination but it must be used to help a non hostile creature within 30'. If the creature succeeds with its roll and you have already used your personal Human Determination it is instantly recharged.

feat.name: Agressive
entries: As a bonus action, you can move up to your speed toward a hostile creature that you can see.

feat.name: Badlander
entries: You gain proficiency in the Survival skill. If you already have proficiency, you gain Expertise in the skill instead, counting your proficiency bonus as doubled.
While traveling in the Badlands, but not the mountains, you and your allies travel at 1.5 times the normal rate.

feat.name: Barbed Hide
entries: One of your ancestors was a barbed devil or other spiky fiend. Barbs protrude from your head. You gain the following benefits:

items: As a bonus action, you can cause small barbs to protrude all over your body or cause them to retract. At the start of each of your turns while the barbs are out, you deal 1d6 piercing damage to any creature grappling you or any creature {@condition grappled} by you.
You gain proficiency in the {@skill Intimidation} skill. If you are already proficient in the skill, you add double your proficiency bonus to checks you make with it.

feat.name: Ripping Horns
entries: You have way more horns than the normal warbreed and they cause gashes on creatures that you grapple.

items: When you successfully grapple a creature you may deal 1d6 + Strength or Dexterity modifier piercing damage to them as part of the attack.
On any turn where you begin the turn grappling a creature you may use your bonus action to deal 1d6 + Strength or Dexterity modifier piercing damage to them.

feat.name: Infernal Constitution
entries: Fiendish blood runs strong in you, unlocking a resilience akin to that possessed by some fiends. You gain the following benefits:

items: You have resistance to cold and poison damage.
You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition poisoned}.

feat.name: Demon Magic
entries: Demonic blood runs strong in you. Choose one cantrip from the following list: Acid Splash, Chill Touch, Fire bolt, or Shocking Grasp. You also learn Cause Fear an Pyrotechnics, each of which you cast once without expending a spell slot. You regain the ability to cast these two spells in this way when you finish a long rest. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for all three spells.

feat.name: Gentle Giant
entries: You tap into the magical connection your race has to nature. You learn one druid cantrip of your choice.

You also learn the Beast Bond and Warding Wind spells, each of which you can cast once without expending a spell slot. You regain the ability to cast these two spells in this way when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for all three spells.

feat.name: Blood of Giants
entries: You harness the giant blood in your veins and grow in size temporarily.

items: As a bonus action you may cast the Enlarge/Reduce spell targetting yourself only using the Enlarge option. You do not need to maintain concentration for this version of the spell. You must complete a long rest before your may do this again.

feat.name: Firbolg Magic
entries: You manifest leathery wings, transforming into an urd. You gain the following benefits:

items: You learn the magic of the primeval woods, which are revered and protected by your people. You learn one druid cantrip of your choice.

You also learn the Longstrider and Pass without Trace spells, each of which you can cast once without expending a spell slot. You regain the ability to cast these two spells in this way when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for all three spells.

feat.name: You Sneaky Little...
entries: You are adept at avoiding danger at others expense.

items: When a creature you can see targets you with an attack, you choose a willing, non hostile creature within 5 feet of you. Using your reaction the two of you swap places, and the chosen creature becomes the target instead.

feat.name: I copy you...
entries: You have learned that copying those around you can be very beneficial.

items: When a non hostile creature you can see makes an attack against a creature you can see with advantage you may do the same against the same creature once on your turn. The advantage is on your first attack and expires at the end of your turn.
If a non hostile creature you can see makes a saving throw with advantage against an effect that you must also save against, you also roll with advantage.

If a non hostile creature you can see makes an ability check with advantage that you must also make, attempting the same task, you may also roll with advantage. You must take a short rest before using this ability again.

feat.name: Mountaineer
entries: From your time living in the mountains you have developed a resistance to the weather and an uncanny ability to traverse rocky terrain.

items: In the mountains you suffer no penalties from difficult terrain.
You gain resistance to cold damage.
In mountainous conditions you have advantage to Atheltics checks to do with climbing, jumping or avoiding a fall by catching onto a ledge or similar.

feat.name: Return the Favor
entries: When you use your Stone's Endurance you mark the offending creature to return the favor. If you hit them with a melee weapon attack before the end of your next turn add the total number of hit points mitigated to the damage of the attack. If this reduces the creature to 0 hit points your Stone's Endurance is instantly refreshed.

feat.name: Momentum
entries: You have learned how to channel your momentum into your attacks. If you move at least 20 feet in a straight line towards your target and then hit with a horn attack the target takes an additional 1d6 damage and must succeed on a strength saving throw (DC = 8 + you proficiency bonus+ your Strength modifier) or be knocked prone.

feat.name: The Herd
entries: When traveling you increase the speed of your group by 50%.

Your bovine legs allow you to ignore any effect that reduces your movement to anything other than 0 for 10 minutes. You activate this ability as part of your movement. You must take a short or long rest before using this ability again. Examples movement impairing conditions that you ignore: penalty for getting up from prone, difficult terrain, plant growth movement reduction, ray of frost cantrip movement reduction.

feat.name: Enlightenment
entries: You have made peace with your savage nature and have gained some degree of enlightenment. You make all saving throws against fear or frightened effects with advantage.

items: You gain resistance to Fire damage.
You are unaffected by the extreme heat, and are immune to exhaustion cause by extreme heat.
You have disadvantage to saving throws to avoid exhaustion due to extreme cold.
When you successfully gain temporary hit points from using your Hungery Jaws ability you may elect to grapple the target creature as part of the attack.
This special grapple uses your jaws and does not require a free hand.
If you are in the water and your target does not possess a swim speed any attacks you make against them during this grapple are made with advantage.
If you successfully reduce the creature to 0 hit points before this grapple ends your Hungry Jaws ability immediately refreshes.

feat.name: Cat's Reflexes
entries: Always aware, quick to react.

items: You can't be surprised while you are conscious.
You do not take damage from a fall of 20' or less.
Getting up from prone costs you 5' of movement instead of the normal amount.

feat.name: Lion's Roar
entries: As an action you let our a Lion's roar forcing each hostile creature within 30 feet of you to make a Wisdom saving throw (DC 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier). A target automatically succeeds on the save if it can't hear you or see you. On a failed save, a target becomes frightened for 1 minute. If the frightened target takes any damage, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success. You must take a short or long rest before you may use this ability again.

feat.name: Panther's Leap
entries: If you use your Feline Agility feature you also double your jumping distance and height.
Pounce. If you move at least 15' in a straight line and hit with a melee weapon attack with a one handed weapon you may as a bonus action immediately attack again with the same weapon.

feat.name: Snake
entries: You may transform into a Giant Poisonous Snake or a Constrictor Snake. The transformation lasts for an hour, or until you drop to 0 hit points or die. You assume the hit points of your new form. When you reverts to your normal form, you return to the number of hit points you had before you transformed. If you revert as a result of dropping to 0 hit points, any excess damage carries over to your normal form. As long as the excess damage doesn't reduce you to 0 hit points, you aren't knocked unconscious. You are limited in the actions you can perform by the nature of your new form, and you can't speak, cast spells, or take any other action that requires hands or speech. You retain your Intelligence, Wisdom and Charisma while in this form. You do not retain your class features but you do retain your race features such as Magic Resistance.

feat.name: The Divine Within
entries: Your introspection has awakened your connection to one of the divines. You learn one cleric cantrip of your choice. You also learn Protection From Evil and Good and Calm Emotions spells, each of which you can cast once without expending a spell slot. You regain the ability to cast these two spells in this way when you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for all three spells.

feat.name: The Savage Within
entries: You have turned away from introspection and meditation and have connected with your ancient predatory nature. Your Yuan-ti snake features become far more pronounced.

items: You gain advantage to any stealth rolls if you are not wearing heavy armour and if you do not move this turn.
As a bonus action you can flick out your tongue and gain blindsight 10' until the end of your turn.
You gain a swim speed equal to your normal movement.

feat.name: Loxodon Magic
entries: Your meditation practice has led to increased magical prowess.

items: You learn the Guidance cantrip and can cast it at will.

You also learn the spells Sanctuary and Enhance Ability each of which you can cast once without expending a spell slot. You regain the ability to cast these spells after you finish a long rest and Wisdom is your spellcasting modifier.

feat.name: Grasping Trunk
entries: You have practiced long and hard to ensure your trunk never lets go.

items: You have advantage on all grapple checks made with your trunk.

When you have a creature grappled with your trunk you can use a bonus action to make a constrict attack with your trunk. Add your Constitution modifier and proficiency bonus to the attack roll for this attack. The attack deals 1d4 + CON of bludgeoning damage.

feat.name: Elemental Mastery
entries: You have always felt a connection to the beasts your kind hunts. The elementals of the Endless Sea could not only be a foe, but a tool as well if treated with care.
You have advantage on any Persuasion (Charisma) checks made in Primordial.

feat.name: Watery Form
entries: You have spent so long beneath the seas that your body has begun to take on the properties of the water that surrounded you. You gain resistance to poison damage.

feat.name: Mastery of Water
entries: Your natural abilities to control the waves increase an extrordinary amount. As long as there is a source of water with as much volume as a bucket or more, you may use your rection to call it to protect you and reduce the damage of a fire attack by half. You must take a short or long rest before you may use this ability again.

deity.name: Igna
deity.title: Goddess Of Light, Fire, The Phoenix, Defeat And Rebirth
entries: She was dead, now returned to life. A cult, known as the Unadorned Ones or Radiant Ones stole Igna’s soma and created their own religion. She was reborn when her champion killed the avatar of the Radiant Ones in the autumn of G26 (24 years ago). Now Igna once again brings fire and light to those that pray to her. Her time in torpor brought her close to death giving her insight past the grave. Unlike the titans, the relentless destroyers, Igna's fire burns away the old to make way for the new.

Followers of Igna are commonly passionate about a cause. They are missionaries with specific goals in mind. They are famous for being willing to *burn* away the old to allow them to accomplish the new. This is done in the name of Igna and the greater good.

Cleric's of Igna are fierce on the battlefield. The more adept ones can hurl balls of fire that destroy the morale of the enemy. These clerics are known for their bright armour and shields as well as their colourful robes. They most often use yellows, oranges and reds.
The phoenix is often associated with Igna.

deity.name: Fekwen
deity.title: Goddess Of Mercantilism
deity.symbol: The signatorius, a small piece of metal stamped with your name and your trade

customProperties.Domains: {@class cleric|phb|Knowledge|Knowledge Domain}, {@class cleric|xge|Forge|Forge Domain}, {@class cleric|ggr|Order|Order Domain}

entries: Fekwen promotes and protects the mercantile venture. Honesty and competition are best virtues. Profit is most desirable. All followers of Fekwen, and merchants of repute, carry a signatorius, a document that identifies where they are from, what they trade in and their names. Fekwen guides the virtuous away from gambling and vice.

Followers of Fekwen often display their signatorius openly, wearing it like a necklace or amulet. They are often merchants or traders. Many are also teachers that work for a commission. The most successful followers are reliable, honest and know when to profit from an opportunity and when to show respect and not try to profit.

The fallen kingdom of Alt Walav was governed by wise and powerful nobles and followers of the goddess of the deal. They often protected the interests of the individual merchant and created a path to success and riches for the entrepreneur.

The nomadic desert tribes of dark elves often contain a priest or two of Fekwen, as trade is integral to their survival. Some of these faithful are arbiters of law, and are sought by the clans to settle disputes both internal and external.

deity.name: Mythral & Kordda
deity.title: Twin Gods Of Battle, Honourable And Dishonourable, Open Conflict And Guerrilla Warfare
deity.symbol: For those that favor Mythral over Kordda, a silver shield with an upward pointing dagger. For those that favor Kordda over Mythral, a black dagger, point down, over a shield.
entries: Mythral is revered by soldiers and generals. Mythral believes in ritually declaring war upon enemies, wearing regalia and using established military tactics. Battle is a religious activity. It should be regarded as such and bringing dishonour upon yourself is a great sin. Mythral's twin has taught him that he must anticipate dishonourable acts. Followers of Mythral choose the higher path.

Kordda is revered by assassins and brawlers. The consequence of battle is what is important. Arrive at victory by any means necessary. Stealth and cunning are to be used for one's advantage. Kordda is not necessarily viewed as evil by all. Many would agree on the term distasteful.

Most of the temples of Mythral are also schools of combat: wrestling schools, mounted combat academies, archery ranges and so on. The temples to Kordda often test the visitors ability to discern their true nature. They may be hidden in plane sight as a tavern or concealed behind hidden doors and tunnels.

deity.name: Thillidan
deity.title: God Of Mysteries, Oceans, Where The Eye Cannot See
deity.symbol: A purple field with waves and octopus tentacles emerging from the depths
entries: The ocean is the unknown, maybe unknowable. To search the depths is to seek out the mysteries of the universe. When one understands the tide, the undercurrents and the deep, one understand the source of all creation. The gods, titans and dragons came from the depths. Thillidan treasures secrets, always pursuing the mysterious.

Thillidan is loyal to the Nine and does not simply horde knowledge. Unused, knowledge is wasteful or simply vain. He is often called upon by the other gods to reveal the secret weaknesses of a particular foe. The Titans hate Thillidan for he often knows their faults and the magic necessary to counter their destructive ways. Hex'a'grum, Titan of Shadows, in particular despises when his secret machinations are revealed by the god of knowledge and mystery.
A sect within the religion, known as Seekers of Truth, are rumoured to hold vast troves of knowledge of all types in a magical library. They travel the world for secrets to add to the archives.

deity.name: Ghem Under The Mountain
deity.title: God Of Mountains, Gems, Diamonds, Iron, And Strength
deity.symbol: A shield with a hammer on it or a mountain with a crown of jewels

customProperties.Domains: {@class cleric|phb|Light|Light Domain}, {@class cleric|phb|Life|Life Domain}, {@class cleric|xge|Forge|Forge Domain}

entries: Adoptive father of the dwarves. Ghem embodies strength. His virtues include working the forge, the brewing of ale, smashing of stone and rock and other feats of strength. Ghem is known for applying strength as a solution to all problems.
The Hammerers, formerly of the kingdom of Thorria, are an order of dwarven paladins that destroy undead and fiends.

deity.name: Liisa The Bountiful One
deity.title: Goddess Of The Hearth, Bounty, Wheat And Corn, The Mill, Fish
deity.symbol: Liisa's symbol changes from place to place, and is often the most bountiful source of food in the region. In the Badlands, Liisa's symbol is the Corino river and a fish.
entries: The bounty, the harvest, the catch, and the herd are all protected by Liisa the giver of food. The hearth and warmth are associated with Liisa. It is not uncommon to have small figurines of Liisa near where a family will eat together. Liisa keeps one disease free and hale and hearty. Liisa is also prayed to for growth and fertility.

deity.name: Busana Of The Moon
deity.title: Goddess Of The Hunt, Poetry, Displays Of Virtue
deity.symbol: An amulet of the moons showing one waxing and one waning moon.
entries: Busana is the master of the hunt as virtue. The hunt is not necessarily about food. One can hunt demons or outlaws. It is the practice, the mastery, the execution of the hunt that concerns Busana. In the moment of death, if Busana is honored, the spirit of the prey is taken and reborn as something or someone virtuous. This replenishes food prey or gives the vile a chance to be redeemed. The moment of death is poetry. Busana’s priests often write about death and her artists depict the kill in their work. Pella and Priad, the dead gods that are now the moons, only glow by Busana’s virtue. She illuminates the path of the nocturnal hunter. Busana values mithril, using the magical metal for decoration and weapons. Established temples have master bowyers that craft the best mithril arrowheads.

deity.name: The Jackal Of Death
deity.title: Goddess Of Death, The Destruction Of Undead
deity.symbol: The black mask of a jackal
entries: In ancient times the Jackal of Death was even feared by the gods themselves. It was said that none could escape her grasp. Rhion changed all of that. He promised immortality to the Great Dragons in exchange for knowledge of Magic and tricked the Jackal into granting it. This infuriated the Jackal and drove her mad for a time.

It is said that during this time Vorgoth'a'grum the destroyer whispered in her ear. They entered a terrible alliance and created the Demon Helm. It wrought two plagues upon the land. At the climax of the second one, some 20 or so years ago, a band of adventurers broke the bond between the Jackal and the Helm. She was returned to the pantheon and welcomed back after a great tribunal.

The Jackal of Death shepherds the faithful dead to the Aetherial, keeping them clear of dangers. Her packs roam both the material plane and the aetherial plane destroying the undead. The Jackal is furious at Vorgoth for fooling her and trapping a great deal of her spirit in the Demon Helm for centuries. The faithful seek retribution for their goddess.

The Jackal encourages each species to hold their own traditions around death as long as they respect her guidance: all must die, all must be put to rest and any precautions necessary should be taken to avoid undeath. A tradition widely upheld in the Badlands is that of the Harpa Ring. This is an ear ring that signifies loyalty to the Jackal. If a corpse is found wearing this ring it is the duty of the faithful to bury them.

deity.name: Rhion
deity.title: Trickster God
entries: To show the truth through illusion and trickery. Find the indirect path to your goal. When the gods grew angry at the mortals and jealously guarded their magic Rhion painted the night sky with the blueprint for arcane magic. The constellations themselves align to the 8 schools of magic. Anyone gifted enough to wrestle with the mysteries in the stars can learn magic. The gods hated Rhion for giving away magic to the world. To make up for it, he tricked Lady Death into making the gods truly immortal and unkillable. And once again Rhion was in favor. And so it goes, over and over, tricking and antagonizing the gods, dragons and old titans only to eventually appease them with some clever restitution.

deity.name: The Twin Moons Pella And Priad
deity.title: The Dead Gods, Defenders of the Material Plane
entries: The moons are the bodies of the dead gods Pella and Priad. It is said that they were first to fight Vorgoth the destroyer titan when he stole the soma of Lady Death and made the destroyer helm plague that nearly ended us all.

deity.name: Circane
deity.title: God Of Storms, Thunder, Sky, Birds Of Prey
deity.symbol: A dark cloud with a lightning bolt
entries: Circane’s nature reflects that of the sky itself. Open and inviting one moment, but in the blink of an eye it can transform into a foreboding, dangerous maelstrom. His impetuous nature carries into his chosen animal, the falcon. It soars above the world on currents of wind but can strike with no warning. Travelers and farmers often pray or make offerings to this minor god, hoping to stop his wrath from acting against them. However, dark and stormy Circane can turn on even the most ardent follower at a moment’s notice.

deity.name: Lutu
deity.title: God Of Mushrooms, Caves, Tunnels Created By Water
entries: This small god once entered into a competition with Ghem to dig the most vast cave network. Ghem used strength and Lutu used water. He won, because water was tireless. Ghem and Lutu do not like each other.

deity.name: Wullo
deity.title: God Of Cats, Exploring Uninvited Places
deity.symbol: A portal with a cat eye peering through
entries: The Cat Lord is known for appear where unwelcome and finding out secrets he was never meant to. It is very uncommon to see worship of this feline deity outside of the Tabaxi communities. When the Car Lord's minions come to a community people tend to double check that they have locked their strongboxes. The Cat Lords minions are less interested in stealing objects, they are after secret knowledge.

It is worth mentioning that the Cat Lord is also a consummate predator, capable of bringing down his foes with weapons and claws. There is a sect of Wullo devotees that hunt for knowledge in forgotten crypts and barrows overcoming the traps and monsters that guard them.

deity.name: Idite
deity.title: Goddess Of Nomads, Pastoralists, Deserts, Sheep & Goats
deity.symbol: A shepherd's crook over a solar disk
entries: The Zuhayre clan, as well as a few offshoots that intermarry with their expatriates, worship an exarch of Liisa as their common ancestor and patron saint. Idite Zuhayre appears as an elderly dark elf woman, wearing simple robes and carrying a shepherd’s crook of polished, many-colored glass. It is believed that in the early days of the world, she wrangled the great golden goat in the sky and now leads it across in an orderly progression of seasons.

deity.name: Alira
deity.title: Goddess Of The Songbird, Keeper Of Lost Songs
entries: Dark elves that are taken as slaves are often prohibited from singing. Not only does this hamper personal and spiritual growth by not being able to sing one’s life song, it also causes a dark elf to slowly lose hold on their family history, traditions, and sense of belonging. It is said that Alira Torar would change shape into a small desert songbird, listening to the songs whispered in the night by captive peoples. She collected songs from different tribes and would flit from town to town carrying the songs of the dark elves on the wind, bringing them hope. Many dark elves that escaped from bondage would travel back to their homeland only to find their tribes had moved on. Guided by visions of songbirds calling to them with familiar tunes, these people without a clan bound together as their own clan under the name Torar. To this day, those without a family for whatever reason stumble upon a welcoming group of Torar by way of a bird, and are brought into the flock. Calling themselves the SongKeepers, the Torar clan seeks to emulate the deeds of their ancestor. They are a scattered tribe that travels amongst merchant towns and nomadic tribes alike, collecting and performing life songs, traditions, and family histories. In this way they strive to inspire hope and make sure that no one is forgotten.

deity.name: Panaar
deity.title: God Of Retribution. Also Known As The Shadow Of Tyrants.
entries: Panaar is a god to the downtrodden and the underdog. He values the just treatment of people, and his name is invoked by those who seek retribution for abuse. A slave might pray to Panaar for their master to mysteriously fall ill, or a group of labourers might rise against their foreman for stealing their wages. A populace might pray for release from the tyranny of a cruel king, and one day wake up to find that he has been poisoned.

Worshippers of Panaar often pay for retributive acts with a single black coin amongst real ones. Over time, this symbol has become broadly emblematic of Panaar. In larger cities, covert methods such as the passing of a black coin are used to avoid detection by those who have good reason to fear Panaar’s wrath.

deity.name: Eterna
deity.title: Goddess Of Immortality, Balm Against Death
deity.symbol: Three waves or three circles or three dots on a plane field
entries: Eterna is a mystery. She is spoke about in stories and myths but no one is known to actively worship her. Monuments honoring this god have been seen in the cursed city of Byzaza. It is not coincidence that the powerful residents are now all immortal mummies.

deity.name: Vorgoth’grum
deity.title: The Ancient Titan Of Decay, Godkiller
entries: In nature, plants decay and become one with the soil. They fertilize the ground and new plants grow. Vorgoth is decay alone, a break in the cycle of life, true death. When Vorgoth destroys a being its spirit is cut from the cycle and consumed by the ancient horror.

Vorgoth is often depicted as a massive entity, impossible to see completely with slippery shadow tentacles whipping in all directions. Of all of the titans, Vorgoth is the most capable of breaching into the world. He frequently grants powers to followers, both Old One Warlocks and Clerics that choose to follow the titan.

It is said that Vorgoth killed the gods Pella and Priad while rampaging and trying to destroy Morra. He was repelled by the other gods but not before planting the seed of decay in The Jackal’s mind. A sick union of the two, Vorgoth and The Jackal, led to the creation of the Demon Helm crisis.

deity.name: Hex'a'grum
deity.title: The Ancient Titan Of Shadow Magic
entries: Hex - To cast a spell, or bewitch.

The ancient titan Hex’a’grum is the root of the word hex. He uses shards of shadow magic to pierce the hearts of his foes and bewitch them, corrupting them to his will. He speaks in whispers. He passes through the dark places in the material plane and through the dark places in his victim’s minds.

Hex is the least obvious of the titans, eschewing the blunt and obvious tactics of his brothers and sisters. And as such, Hex is the most ever present on the material plane. They say that Hex can pull the spirit of one he has corrupted from their body the moment before death and guide them to his part of the Aetherial plane, consuming his victim for power, or perhaps storing them for some later purpose.

Shadow beings and shadow weapons may not all be the servants of Hex, but they can all trace their origins back to him. There are legends of armies of shadows conjured out of thin air to savage those that betray an pact to Hex.
Warlocks with the Hexblade Patron have entered a bond with this mighty Shadow Titan.

deity.name: Carriba’grum
deity.title: The Ancient Titan Of Cannibalism
entries: Cannibalism is to eat the flesh of one’s own race. Cannibalism is reviled in most cultures because it alerts Carriba to your darkest hungers and desires. Carriba promises power to those that continue to eat and corrupts the spirit to become addicted to flesh.
Carriba is often visualized as a small woman with a almost comically large mouth filled with rows of razor shark teeth.
Cannibalism is a serious problem in the Badlands. In some regions, notable the swamp near New Hope, there are entire cannibal cultures openly hunting and eating their own kind

deity.name: Miser’a’grum
deity.title: The Ancient Titan Of Misery, Dark Places, Being Dragged Underground, Collapse, Cave Ins, and Avalanches
entries: The ancient titan Miser’a’grum lives under the world in the Deep Below. Her true disciples are driders. She is the essence of being dragged down into the dark depths of the earth and killed… by a collapse or cave in, by an avalanche or other catastrophe. She also enjoys suffocating her prey.

deity.name: Des'a'Grum
deity.title: The Titan Of Poison And Pollution
entries: The mortal enemy of Liisa, Des poisons and pollutes the world, making it barren and lifeless. Whether buried under lava, drowned in toxic gases, or frozen solid, Des’s power creates a land so hostile that nothing can survive. Some say the Badlands themselves were cursed by Des long ago.

Des’s mortal followers are those so barren of empathy that they will happily condemn others to a slow death for selfish reasons. Few of its cultists understand Des’s true nature. Its creations are bizarre, half living aberrations that bear no resemblance to the natural living inhabitants of Morra. Their mad gibberings bring visions of yawning vistas devoid of life, a cosmos with no place left for the fragile flesh of our kind.

deity.name: Anim’a’grum
deity.title: The Ancient Titan Of Corrupted Souls, The Soul Collector
entries: Anim’a’grum, commonly known as Animus, is a collector of souls. He seeks to extinguish life, and use those souls to act as agents to collect more.

He is commonly depicted as a massive, corpulent creature, so full on his bounty of the eternal essences of the once living. His servants do his bidding, both in his home in the Aetherial as well as in world of the living.
Necromancers and intelligent undead are often servants of this dark creature and many cults have sprung up throughout time that serve him.

deity.name: Aentroph'a'grum
deity.title: The Ancient Titan Of Chaos And Change
entries: Aentroph'a'grum views the world and its natural order as a mistake, especially civilization. He seeks to destroy everything and twist reality into a reflection of his own whims, similar to his domain on the Amalgoreal plane. He has few minions in the world that serve him knowingly, but many less intelligent beings may be duped by one of his extraplanar followers into carrying out his will. They work to destroy small parts of the world through sowing mistrust among allies, breaking down societies, and wanton destruction.

He is commonly depicted as a amoeba with a brain as the nucleus and his domain on the Amalgoreal shifts shape according to his whims, often made up of interlocking spheres or areas with impossible geometry, but just as likely to look like a rough-hewn cavern or a ruined marble palace.
